column297: 09/Jun/05 4:04 AM;mjelle;The mapping.xml file is specified with JSR 109, and it allows for java primitives to be present. Apache Axis wscompile do not generate primitives also, but still they allowed this _one_ line of code, to comform to JSR 109.
column298: 09/Jun/05 4:10 AM;thomas.diesler;Please quote the conformance requirement in JSR109 that backs up your last comment
column299: 09/Jun/05 4:11 AM;mjelle;Also, remember that we don't always have the privilige to generate things. We simple get a completed EAR file, with webservices generated according to specifications, but now we simply can't deploy them on JBoss.
column300:
09/Jun/05 4:14 AM;thomas.diesler;Martin is right, JSR109 says

"The java-xml-type-mapping element contains a java-type that is the fully qualified name of the Java class, primitive type, or array type, QName of the XML root type or anonymous type, the WSDL type scope the QName applies to and the set of variable mappings for each public variable within the Java class."
column301: 09/Jun/05 4:17 AM;mjelle;Damn... that was fast. Stupid acrobat pdf search didn't find primitives anywhere, so was trying to dig though the spec.

column1: JTS TransactionManagerDelegate is creating two copies of the TransactionManagerImple
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54: TransactionManagerDelegate passes a new TransactionManagerImple to the super constructor instead of supplying the one cached in a local static during static initialization.
column293: 19/Jul/07 5:54 AM;adinn;fixed by revision 13629

column1: TransactionImple::endSuspendedRMs may dive out before ending all XAResources
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54: TransactionImple::endSuspendedRMs loops through all enlisted XAResources sending them an end() as a precursor to commit or rollback. It is supposed to notify all resources even if one (or more) of them throws an exception, returning true iff they all complete. As currently coded it returns failure at the first exception, potentially omitting some of the end() calls.
column56:
Modified TransactionImple::endSuspendedRMs to ensure all suspended resources are sent and end() even if one barfs.
This still needs testing in an appropriately convoluted test case (i.e. multiple suspended resources, one of which takes exception to being ended).;11/Jul/07 12:13 PM;adinn;1800
column293: 10/Dec/08 6:22 AM;adinn;This has been fixed but there is not yet any test case for it.

column1: BaseTransaction swallows a critical error message
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54:
Patch is against the latest trunk, r13242.

JTA's base transaction throws NotSupportedException for attempts to begin a nested transaction. However, the root cause's message is lost which forces one into scratching his head and diving into all kinds of debug hell. The patch propagates the message, which is quite descriptive and save from late night debugging sessions :)
column293: 10/Jul/07 5:03 AM;adinn;Commited patch to trunk ArjunaJTA/jta/classes/com/arjuna/ats/internal/jta/transaction/arjunacore/BaseTransaction.java revision 13294

column295: 13/Jul/07 3:59 AM;adinn;Hmm, that will be the JTS version, eh? Ok, I'll patch that too.
column296: 13/Jul/07 4:03 AM;marklittle;Yes, that's the one. Whenever updating anything to do with JTA, check both source trees just in case.

column294:
17/Jul/07 7:07 AM;adinn;The short answer is no you cannot replace the map with a ConcurrentHashMap. The map in question is implemented by wrapping a WeakHashMap with a SynchronizedMap. This has different semantics to a ConcurrentHashMap -- changing it would trade off a contention problem against a garbage problem.

The long answer is that thecontention is happening because of an inefficiency in the way the AS/TM code is implementing reclamation of map entries for dead transactions. A WeakHashMap works in conjunction with the GC to remove entries keyed by objects to which there are no other references (in this case the Transaction instance is the map key). So, your problem will manifest under load immediately after GC when a new local transaction is started and an update of the WeakHashMap occurs. The updating thread will lock the table and then find that a whole load of dead Transaction instances have been notified by the GC. Before it can do the update the thread has to remove the dead entries and, possibly, downsize the map table. This can take a long time and explains why the getSynchronization call  in your trace is stalled

The solution is for the AS/TM to make sure that the information maintained in this map is cleared out as transactions are resolved rather than relying upon the GC. I am working on a fix.
column295: 19/Jul/07 5:43 AM;adinn;The current(WeakHashMap) implementation works round a problem with synchronization execution order dependencies. It is required until synchronization ordering can be implemented in both  the local JTA and JTS.

This was a possibility at the time but I can't remember the reason for not doing it.
column297: 23/Jul/07 4:09 AM;adinn;Yes, that would be easy to do. However, Mark does not want the jtax layer to  use any non-standard hooks into the JTA/JTS codebase. That way the AS can maintain interoperability with other Transaction Service implementations. So, we must only rely on the javax.transaction API. Was that the rationale for not using the transaction implementation last time?

column1: Interrupt reaper thread
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54: It is possible for the reaper thread to become blocked when telling a transaction to rollback. We should have another thread that interrupts the reaper thread if it has been blocked for more than a configurable amount of time on the same transaction. In this case, the reaper could either put the transaction back on the list and try again later, or just mark it as rollback_only. My preference would actually be to have a separate list of blocked transactions that are marked as rollback_only and have the reaper try to roll them back again later.

column1: XAError during commit is reported as retriable by the participant when it should be a heuristic
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54:
An XAException with errorcode -7 is RMFAIL, which means that the transaction coordinator does not know what state the resource manager is in. It may have committed or it may have rolled back (it could have done this autonomously). This may be a permanent failure of the resource manager or it may only be transient; the transaction manager has no way of knowing. At this point the transaction outcome is potentially non-atomic (an heuristic outcome) and outside the scope of the TM to try to resolve automatically. 

In ATS 4.0.2, the failure during commit was masked and commit would return committed. What happened was that the failed resource was retained in the transaction log and recovery would try to complete the transaction later. This silent behaviour was wrong (a bug): the application needs to know that a potential heuristic outcome has occurred. Therefore, in ATS 4.0.3 the error is handled differently (correctly): the transaction will throw a heuristic exception and, as before, retain the reference to the XAResource in the hopes that the log can be used to resolve the potential heuristic. 

The failure recovery subsystem retry mechanism has not changed. However, because the failure reported from the XAResource has changed, this impacts what failure recovery will do. In 4.0.2, the error (wrongly) was reported as being something that failure recovery could automatically try to deal with. Hence, when the recovery manager ran and found the log entry that referenced your XAResource, it would try to complete the transaction. In 4.0.3, the error is a heuristic, which cannot be managed automatically: that is the whole point of a heuristic error. It needs manual intervention. In this case, the recovery manager will ignore the log entry and do nothing.

column299:
07/Jul/06 1:10 PM;kconner;And I should have added that I stated the following in our unfinished conversation on IM.

The correct location to enforce any resource specific policy is in the resource, i.e. the driver (by not supporting the setTransactionTimeout) or the server (by restricting the set of allowable values).  A global setting is inappropriate.  According to the API, the setTransactionTimeout is not required to be supported nor honoured.

I also find it ironic that you are quoting the same BEA documentation that I was quoting in a recent case.  :-)
column300:
07/Jul/06 6:09 PM;marklittle;The document shows that it is configurable within WL and shows the reason why (which is what I had previously discussed). There is no one "correct location" to enforce this policy. It is often easier for sys admins to manage this within the TM configuration, particularly in a distributed environment where different interposed coordinators can have different runtime configuration options such as this. Furthermore, not everyone has the ability or the capability to add new XAResource implementations and ensure they are picked up (and driven correctly) by the application server. This does not have to be a global setting: it's configured on a per instance basis - different runtimes can see different values, which comes back to what I said before in the context of interposition.

We can debate this for ages, but I want a configurable option for this. I believe there are good reasons for it and you have yet to prove that the absence of a configurable option is superior to its presence. Yet another benefit is the fact that customers migrating from WL may be using this option within their applications and expect it to be honoured.

I find it ironic that you used the argument "WL does it this way so we should too so it must be right" for the calling pattern, and yet don't accept the same argument back ;-)
column301:
08/Jul/06 4:49 AM;kconner;Actually, my argument for the calling pattern was "WL always makes the calls in this order so we know that they believe it works with all databases they support".  ;-)

If I remember correctly you rejected this argument yet now you employ it :-).

If the intention is to support customers migrating from WL then I assume we will also have this disabled by default?
column302: 08/Jul/06 5:15 AM;marklittle;Add the configurable attribute. I'm not that bothered what the default is, as long as it's documented. You make that choice.
column303:
18/Jul/06 5:14 AM;kconner;The order of the method invocations has been swapped and the setTransactionTimeout is now configurable.

There are two ways to configure this functionality
 - specify the com.arjuna.ats.jta.xaTransactionTimeoutEnabled property (defaults to true)
 - programmatically using the setXATransactionTimeoutEnabled method on com.arjuna.ats.jta.common.Configuration
  (Boolean.TRUE/enabled, Boolean.FALSE/disabled, null/use property value)

column1: Delay start of recovery manager
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54:
Currently the Recovery Manager begins working as soon as JBossAS starts. When the local JTA implementation is used and there is a transaction to recover, we get the following stack trace:

10:52:35,529 WARN  [loggerI18N] [com.arjuna.ats.internal.jta.resources.arjunacore.restorestate] [com.arjuna.ats.interna\
l.jta.resources.arjunacore.restorestate] Exception on attempting to restore XAResource
java.io.StreamCorruptedException: unexpected end of block data
        at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject0(ObjectInputStream.java:1321)
        at java.io.ObjectInputStream.defaultReadFields(ObjectInputStream.java:1912)
        at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readSerialData(ObjectInputStream.java:1836)
        at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readOrdinaryObject(ObjectInputStream.java:1713)
        at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject0(ObjectInputStream.java:1299)
        at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject(ObjectInputStream.java:339)
        at com.arjuna.ats.internal.jta.resources.arjunacore.XAResourceRecord.restore_state(XAResourceRecord.java:879)
        at com.arjuna.ats.arjuna.coordinator.BasicAction.restore_state(BasicAction.java:1410)
        at com.arjuna.ats.arjuna.coordinator.BasicAction.activate(BasicAction.java:711)
        at com.arjuna.ats.arjuna.coordinator.BasicAction.activate(BasicAction.java:673)
        at com.arjuna.ats.arjuna.recovery.RecoverAtomicAction.<init>(RecoverAtomicAction.java:60)
        at com.arjuna.ats.internal.arjuna.recovery.AtomicActionRecoveryModule.doRecoverTransaction(AtomicActionRecovery\
Module.java:178)

This is because the rest of the system isn't yet fully initialised. The next periodic run of recovery does not suffer this problem and recovery completes successfully. We should look at delaying the start of the Recovery Manager until JBossAS is fully initialised.

column1: Update transactional JDBC driver to support JDBC 3 methods.
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column56:
Added ConnectionImpleJDBC3 with wrapper methods for JDBC3 specific methods, making it a subclass of ConnectionImple. Minor changes to method visibility in the base class to support this.
Modified build system to compile ConnectionImpleJDBC3 only when building on JDK > 1.4, as it links against the 1.5 JDBC Connection API.
Modified  ConnectionManager to load the JDBC3 wrapper using reflection if running on JDK > 1.4, otherwise use the default JDBC2 wrapper. This prevents the ConnectionManager linking against the JDBC3 class, allowing it to be used with the older JDK.
Refactored existing JDBC2Test and added new JDBC3Test as a subclass of it, with test methods to exercise the methods added to the Connection API in JDBC 3. Ran the tests sucessfully against Oracle 10g on linux using JDBC thin drivers.;06/Oct/06 9:15 AM;jhalliday;57600

column1: The installation notes incorrectly specify the initialisation of both TS interceptors.
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54:
The installation notes incorrectly specify the initialisation of both the standard context interceptor and the interposition interceptor.  These interceptors are mutually exclusive.

The symptom exhibited by this problem is OutOfMemoryErrors being logged to the standard output.  This occurs because the interposition interceptor incorrectly interprets part of a text string as a length (approx 1GB).

Investigation lead to the creation of this issue.

column1: Install notes for JTS do not include dependency for the ORB
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54:
The install notes produced as part of the 4.2 release do not specify the dependency of the transaction manager service on the corba service.

The mbean specification in server/all/jboss-service.xml should be:

<mbean code="com.arjuna.ats.jbossatx.jts.TransactionManagerService"
   name="jboss:service=TransactionManager">
   <depends>jboss:service=CorbaORB</depends>
   <attribute name="TransactionTimeout">300</attribute>
</mbean>

column1: Over use of IllegalStateException in JTA commit/rollback
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54: Currently if a transaction has timed out (or been committed/rolled back by another thread) then when a subsequent thread tries to terminate it, we will throw the IllegalStateException rather than an exception which maps to the termination state of the transaction. This is because that's the approach used in the OTS: distinguish between a thread being able to terminate a transaction itself or finding that the transaction has been terminated by another thread. However, this isn't correct in terms of the JTA specification.
column56:
Added InactiveTransactionException, inline with the OTS SystemException.
;11/Apr/06 6:16 AM;marklittle;1800
column293: 11/Apr/06 4:03 AM;marklittle;It is still important to distinguish these cases as in the OTS, so add a specific SystemException type.

column1: Track down bug in CVS version of DTF
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54: A bug has shown itself in the version of DTF compiled from CVS.  An EOFException is being generated on the services side of the results collator.
column56:
Initial investigation of the network traffic showed that the test node client was closing the socket connection to the results collator.  A quick examination of the test node code lead to the cause.

A class in the test node was initialising the socket in an implementation of an abstract method called from a superclass' constructor.  This would then be cleared when the class' constructor ran.  Finalisation of the socket instance lead to the closing of the connection.  This was fixed.

A comparison of the build jar file with the production version showed there were a number of differences between the released version and the CVS version.   Examination of the different classes suggested a previous tag may have been released.  This was verified by comparing the jar built from the tag against the production release.

The current CVS head is tagged as DTF_3_10 and is broken.  The released version is DTF_3_9.  There is also a branch for DTF_4_0 with contains numerous differences from the production release.

Richard is now working on the DTF_3_9 tag as this matches the released version working in production.;06/Apr/06 10:39 AM;kconner;14400
column293:
24/May/06 7:44 AM;kconner;Initial investigation of the network traffic showed that the test node client was closing the socket connection to the results collator. A quick examination of the test node code lead to the cause.

A class in the test node was initialising the socket in an implementation of an abstract method called from a superclass' constructor. This would then be cleared when the class' constructor ran. Finalisation of the socket instance lead to the closing of the connection. This was fixed.

A comparison of the build jar file with the production version showed there were a number of differences between the released version and the CVS version. Examination of the different classes suggested a previous tag may have been released. This was verified by comparing the jar built from the tag against the production release.

The current CVS head is tagged as DTF_3_10 and is broken. The released version is DTF_3_9. There is also a branch for DTF_4_0 with contains numerous differences from the production release.

Richard is now working on the DTF_3_9 tag as this matches the released version working in production.

column1: Ensure ATS logging capabilities are compatible with JBoss
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54: ATS has its own way of logging errors, warnings, debugging etc. Although it follows JDK 1.4 logging specification (and can use log4j as an implementation), we need to ensure it is compatible with the standard way of logging in the result of JBoss.
column56:
Added new logger plugin class, JakartaRelevelingLogger, to TS common module, along with associated object factory.
This impl currently changes the level of INFO messages to DEBUG before passing them to the underlying log4j.

Added new constant value, "log4j_releveler", to allow selection of this logger via. the com.arjuna.common.util.logger property.

Dusted off common logging tests, including necessary changes to the TS build system to compile them. Tested the new plugin standalone.

Added code to the JBossAS integration module (JTA and JTS TransactionManagerService mbeans) , to override logging config setting and use the new plug whenever running inside the app server. Tested against JBossAS beta1. Note: This relies on static initializer blocks as logging can't be changed after it's first used. This could be made less ugly.
;08/Dec/06 9:19 AM;jhalliday;28800
column293: 10/Jan/06 5:26 AM;kevinconner;Moved to JBoss account
column294: 13/Nov/06 6:55 AM;marklittle;It appears that the definition of INFO we use within JBossTS is more appropriate to TRACE when running within JBossAS. Look at adding a mapper from INFO-to-TRACE when running in AS. Should be possible to add another level of indirection (via a logger plugin) that does that and have the plugin used only when running within the application server. That way, we don't adversely affect any existing users of JBossTS who are happy with INFO output.
column295:
08/Dec/06 9:23 AM;jhalliday;see also:
http://www.jboss.com/index.html?module=bb&op=viewtopic&t=93949
http://wiki.jboss.org/wiki/Wiki.jsp?page=UsageOfLoggingLevels
http://docs.jboss.org/process-guide/en/html/internationalization.html

The automatic rewriting of log levels is potentially confusing for new users who are looking at the source code, running it inside the app server and wondering why they don't see the expected messages. I've got a nasty feeling this will come back to bite us in support issues, but we'll give it a try.
column296: 08/Dec/06 9:32 AM;marklittle;Can you add something to the documentation (the section around application server integration)? If you want, send me text and I'll put it in place.

column1: Move atsintegration module from JTS
column11: The JBoss Transaction Manager project.
column54: Currently all integration with application servers is handled within the atsintegration module to reduce dependencies on the main codebase. However, this module resides in the ArjunaJTS product, which means that even if you want to only integrate ArjunaJTA (the local JTA implementation) within an application server (e.g., JBoss), you still need a full build of the JTS. Given that ArjunaJTA will become the default JTA implementation and JTS will be an optional add-on, this integration module needs moving out of JTS.
column56: The atsintegration code has been removed from the JTS codebase.  It is now possible to independently build atsintegration for JTA and JTS.;14/Mar/06 6:13 PM;kconner;86400

column56:
The conversion of ArjunaJTS into CVS has involved numerous issues.

The original import of the codebase into labs has not yet happened, due primarily to issues importing historical data into subversion.  The last decision was to import a snapshot of the current code into a public repository but this has been stalled until we get a response from the JBoss lawyers.

A new repository was setup in the Newcastle office to hold the imported data and ArjunaJTS was imported.  The codebase has been modified so that ArjunaJTS can now be built standalone.;14/Mar/06 6:04 PM;kconner;144000
column293: 08/Mar/06 12:09 PM;marklittle;Waiting for lawyers before we can import to public svn. However, we have imported to a private svn.
column294: 03/Apr/06 9:02 AM;kconner;The local repository was moved over to labs earlier today.

column54:
Eric Brown wrote:
Damon Sicore wrote:
Are these referrers as well?

Yes

Correction... this does NOT include *ANY* referrers.  This is
all requests for blog feeds.  I meant NO above, but rote YES
b/c I am trying not to say no so often... as advised by my
therapist.

[root@colo-br-02 log]# grep 64.74.196.146 localhost_access2006-09-27.log
| grep "GET /jbossBlog/" | wc -l
  77793
[root@colo-br-02 log]# grep 64.74.196.146 localhost_access2006-09-27.log
| grep jbossBlog | wc -l
  77793
[root@colo-br-02 log]#

On Sep 28, 2006, at 9:19 AM, Eric Brown wrote:

I need some feedback here... otherwise, I will simply blackhole
the labs box from talking to the jboss.com site.

Eric Brown wrote:
[root@colo-br-02 log]# grep 64.74.196.146 
localhost_access2006-09-27.log
| grep jbossBlog | wc -l
  62340
[root@colo-br-02 log]#

64.74.196.146 - - [27/Sep/2006:00:00:28 -0500] "GET
/jbossBlog/blog/?flavor=rss2 HTTP/1.1" 200 63978 "-" "Java/1.5.0_07"

So about 70-80k hits a day from Labs to the RSS feeds of jboss.com
and the blojsom instance.  Can you guys explain this?  It's been
going on for a while from what I can see in the logs (months).

--
Eric
column293:
29/Sep/06 8:10 PM;ebrown;It's been going on for a while, but seems to be load related.  It almost looks like the rss feed is getting pulled from jboss.com *every time* someone hits the blog page on labs.

column54:
Shotoku must provide a repository that doesn't require the use of either the JCR or Subversion.  This repository will contain only a very basic set of features:

1.  Simple revisioning (no branching, merging)
2.  Simple Properties

And almost nothing more.  We want to be able to use Shotoku in environments where the app server or an svn server is not present.

column1: Can't serialize "new Class[] {Object[].class}"
column11: An alternative serialization implementation.
column54:
When I attept to serialize array of Class-es, where the first Class is an array class, I'm getting the following stacktrace:

Caused by: java.lang.ClassCastException: java.lang.Class
	at org.jboss.serial.persister.ArrayPersister.saveObjectArray(ArrayPersister.java:106)
	at org.jboss.serial.persister.ArrayPersister.writeData(ArrayPersister.java:101)
	at org.jboss.serial.objectmetamodel.ObjectDescriptorFactory.describeObject(ObjectDescriptorFactory.java:275)
	at org.jboss.serial.objectmetamodel.DataContainer$DataContainerDirectOutput.writeObject(DataContainer.java:197)
	at org.jboss.serial.persister.ArrayPersister.saveObjectArray(ArrayPersister.java:110)
	at org.jboss.serial.persister.ArrayPersister.writeData(ArrayPersister.java:101)
	at org.jboss.serial.objectmetamodel.ObjectDescriptorFactory.describeObject(ObjectDescriptorFactory.java:275)
	at org.jboss.serial.objectmetamodel.DataContainer$DataContainerDirectOutput.writeObject(DataContainer.java:197)
	at org.jboss.serial.io.JBossObjectOutputStream.writeObjectOverride(JBossObjectOutputStream.java:181)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeObject(ObjectOutputStream.java:298)

I see in ObjectDescriptorFactory in the method describeObject() the following code:
        if (obj instanceof Class)
        {
        	metaData = ClassMetamodelFactory.getClassMetaData((Class)obj ...
        } 
        else
        {
           	metaData = ClassMetamodelFactory.getClassMetaData(obj.getClass()...

I don't know why Class objects are handled in a special way here, but later in this method there is

            Persister persister = PersistResolver.resolvePersister(obj,metaData);

which incorrectly gives ArrayPersister, because "metaData" describes not "obj", but some array which is not being serialized at all.

column56: time spent over the weekend fixing this issue;24/Apr/06 9:24 PM;clebert.suconic;108000
column293:
21/Apr/06 10:31 PM;clebert.suconic;The problem basicaly is related to Class references.
Java Serializatio treats Classes as regular references, hence once a class is written the class is only written once.

With JBoss Serialization I'm describing the classname and Classfields every time a object is serialized. 
After fixed that, the size of JBossSerialization streaming is going to be <= JavaSerialization. This should be fixed in two or three days now.

column1: Eliminate third libraries dependencies
column11: An alternative serialization implementation.
column54:
It would be easier to reuse JBossSerialization outside of JBoss if wasn't required libraries like jboss-commons and log4j.

For this matter we will use System Properties to activate/deactivate logging and debugging.

We will use org.jboss.serial.LogLevel, which default will be 0,
and org.jboss.serial.LogFile (if not specified the default will be System.out)

column1: Modify DBUnitSeamTest to permit use of DTDs generated by DBUnit
column11: JBoss Seam is an application framework for Java EE 5. Seam unifies the component models of JSF and EJB 3.0, providing a streamlined programming model for web-based enterprise applications. Forum available here.
column54:
Given: DBUnit's behavior is such that if the first row to be loaded (via DataSetOperation) into a table doesn't have all columns present, those columns will be dropped in every row loaded thereafter.

Given: If a DTD is present, DBUnit will honor it, and refrain from the aforementioned behavior. DBUnit has a facility to generate said DTD.

Given: The current DBUnitSeamTest (for which I am grateful indeed) doesn't permit specification of said DTD's location. Hence, I must manually massage my test data to ensure that the first row loaded into each table has values for all columns, which causes considerable inconvenience in my automated testing flow (which includes data generation).

Request:  Modify DBUnitSeamTest to permit use of DTDs generated by DBUnit

column1: validateAll ignores @NotNull and @NotEmpty
column11: JBoss Seam is an application framework for Java EE 5. Seam unifies the component models of JSF and EJB 3.0, providing a streamlined programming model for web-based enterprise applications. Forum available here.
column54:
when i use s:valiadateAll and put a text field inside where the matching hibernate field has @NotEmpty set, no validation error will be raised if i submit without entering text.
this is because JSF ignores the validators because the field is empty and not marked as required.
therefore the ValidateAllRenderer will need to check for these validators and call evt.setRequired(true) as needed.

I can get a the conversation picker to render!
If I hit the destory button then it does not destroy the conversation it seems as its still displayed and the conversation-id in the address bar reamisn the same!

It stays displayed  until after I call an @End on the conversation.

At this point the conversation still is not killed, BUT the display of the conversation now stops!

This is a VERY VERY simple seam app!



<!DOCTYPE pages PUBLIC
          "-//JBoss/Seam Pages Configuration DTD 1.2//EN"
          "http://jboss.com/products/seam/pages-1.2.dtd">

<!-- no-conversation-view-id sends the user to a given screen if there is no conversation when the given page is accessed -->
<!-- timeout will keep the bean alive a lot longer than the session timeout so it will not be removed whilst the session is still reasonably "active" -->
<pages no-conversation-view-id="/pages/prospectRegistration.xhtml">

	<!-- Gives conversations a name to make the visible in the coversation picker -->
    <page view-id="/pages/prospectRegistration.xhtml" timeout="300000" action="#{conversation.begin}">
        Reason: Registration of Prospect
    </page>

	<!-- Gives conversations a name to make the visible in the coversation picker -->
    <page view-id="/pages/prospectRegistrationSuccessful.xhtml" timeout="300000">
        Reason: Successful Registration of Prospect
    </page>

</pages>




    /* (non-Javadoc)
     * @see org.adscale.prospect.ProspectRegistrationController#processDetails()
     */
    public String process() {
        log.debug(">processUserDetails" +prospect.toString());
        facesMessages.addFromResourceBundle(FacesMessage.SEVERITY_INFO, "prospect_registered_successfully");
        em.persist(prospect);
        log.debug("<processUserDetails");
        return "success";
    }
    
    /* (non-Javadoc)
     * @see org.adscale.prospect.ProspectRegistrationController#finish()
     */
    public String finish() {               <<<<<<<<----- Putting @End on this does not change the conversationId, but it DOES stop the conversation picker displaying anyhting..
        log.debug(">finish");
        log.debug("<finish");
        return "gotoProspectRegistration";
    }

    /* (non-Javadoc)
     * @see org.adscale.prospect.ProspectRegistrationController#destroy()
     */
    @Remove @Destroy
    public void destroy() {
        log.debug(">destroy");
        log.debug("<destroy");
    }

column1: doublequotes not escaped in strings in a DRL rules RHS
column11: The legacy JIRA project for Drools. Now use DROOLS JIRA project please.
column54:
There is a problem with "-s inside string literals.

Example:
rule "test_Quotes"
   when
      InitialFact()
   then
      String s = "\"";
end
results in DRL compilation error:
[mTokens, mSTRING]: line 14:0 mismatched char: '?' on line 14; expecting char '"'
(line 14 is the last line in the file)
column56:
Hello,

I modified drl.g file to fix parsing of quotes:

--- drl.g	2006-08-17 21:59:02.000000000 +0200
+++ drl.g	2006-10-18 18:04:34.021232000 +0200
@@ -1080,8 +1080,31 @@
 	;
 	
 STRING
-	:	('"' ( options{greedy=false;} : .)* '"' ) | ('\'' ( options{greedy=false;} : .)* '\'')
-	;
+    :  ('"' ( EscapeSequence | ~('\\'|'"') )* '"')
+     | ('\'' ( EscapeSequence | ~('\\'|'\'') )* '\'')
+    ;
+
+fragment
+HexDigit : ('0'..'9'|'a'..'f'|'A'..'F') ;
+
+fragment
+EscapeSequence
+    :   '\\' ('b'|'t'|'n'|'f'|'r'|'\"'|'\''|'\\')
+    |   UnicodeEscape
+    |   OctalEscape
+    ;
+
+fragment
+OctalEscape
+    :   '\\' ('0'..'3') ('0'..'7') ('0'..'7')
+    |   '\\' ('0'..'7') ('0'..'7')
+    |   '\\' ('0'..'7')
+    ;
+
+fragment
+UnicodeEscape
+    :   '\\' 'u' HexDigit HexDigit HexDigit HexDigit
+    ;
 	
 BOOL
 	:	('true'|'false')

I'm not sure this is a good way to fix the problem. Should code inside then clause be parsed in any way?
Maybe there is some way to ommit normal lexer behaviour on RHS code?;18/Oct/06 12:15 PM;tomasz.cichocki;28800
column57:
Hello,

I modified grammar of DRL files. See modified_drl-single_token.g attachment.
I think approach used in this grammar solves problems with parsing code of actions and functions.
DSL in RHS of rules isn't supported by thes grammar yet...;20/Oct/06 11:53 AM;tomasz.cichocki;28800

column294:
20/Oct/06 11:47 AM;tomasz.cichocki;Modified DRL grammar file.

Body of a function and body of a rule is read as single token -- fixed problems parsing code used in actions and functions.
DSL not supported in RHS.

column1: getUnmarshaller always calls Class.forName operation for creating Unmarshallers
column11: The purpose of JBoss Remoting is to provide a single API for most network based invocations and related service that uses pluggable transports and data marshallers.  The JBoss Remoting API provides the ability for making synchronous and asynchronous remote calls, push and pull callbacks, and automatic discovery of remoting servers.  The intention is to allow for the addition of different transports to fit different needs, yet still maintain the same API for making the remote invocations and only requiring configuration changes, not code changes, to fit these different needs.
column54:
MarshalFactory.getUnMarshaller is always considering dataType as null for a regular invocation on JBoss. 
As a consequence, it will always call Class.forName which is a synchronized method what will prevent scalability on multiple CPUs.
column294:
20/Sep/05 4:36 PM;clebert.suconic;Tom... by doing that simple change, I could make the InvocationLayer 20% faster, and the timing was stable. Before this change I had some invocations taking a long time, and some other invocations doing pretty quick. In other words this is bein much more stable for this small change.


Can you please confirm if that change is okay?

column1: Remove dependency from JBossSerialization
column11: The purpose of JBoss Remoting is to provide a single API for most network based invocations and related service that uses pluggable transports and data marshallers.  The JBoss Remoting API provides the ability for making synchronous and asynchronous remote calls, push and pull callbacks, and automatic discovery of remoting servers.  The intention is to allow for the addition of different transports to fit different needs, yet still maintain the same API for making the remote invocations and only requiring configuration changes, not code changes, to fit these different needs.
column54:
JBossSerialization should always be accessed through SerializationManager.

There is a dependency right now, on sending a reset and a stupid Boolean object to reset on ObjectOUtputStream, but not on JbossSerialization.
So, JbossRemoting needs to know the object type because of that need.

JBoss Profiler allows monitoring of key operating metrics such as CPU and memory in production environment. Subsequently it offers tools for analysis and troubleshooting of enterprise applications based on statistics collected in production. While many tools focus on development time application profiling, generally they do not address memory leaks and CPU spike problems that occur sporadically in production after days of normal operation. 

JBoss Profiler is an aspect applied at the JBoss MicroContainer level and is specifically tuned for low impact, high value data collection.

column1: Maven2 poms initial version ready for portal
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
The _maven directory will contain a complete maven2 build environment for the jboss portal

prepare:
          If you are running windows --> install cygwin and run bash from here
          1) #install maven2 (2.0.6) or later
          2) #install the jboss-packaging-maven-plugin
             svn co https://svn.codehaus.org/mojo/trunk/mojo/mojo-sandbox/jboss-packaging-maven-plugin jboss-packaging-maven-plugin
             mvn -f jboss-packaging-maven-plugin/pom.xml install
          3) #install the portal
             svn co http://anonsvn.jboss.org/repos/portal/trunk jboos-portal
             cd jboss-portal
             build/build.sh clean most
          4) unzip the _maven into jboss-portal

          5) cd _maven
             cd _deploy
             # deploy the third party artifacts that I did not find on the internet
             # edit the script to meet your settings before running
             ./third-party-deploy.sh

          6) #prepare the maven source locations
usage:       #run script
             ./_build.sh

post steps:
          7) #maven build the jboss 2.6 portal
             mvn clean install

The maven-jbossaop-plugin cannot specify classes, but takes all classes in target/classes

column297:
13/Sep/06 6:12 PM;sverker;Ok, after a lot of working with the debugger and following the flow I've made the neccesary changes. It works beautifully now, if I may say it myself.

The attached patch and files are on the 2.4 branch but shouldn't bee too hard to port to head once we've agreed on a few design questions that needs to be discussed.

With this patch, if a war file contains an *-object.xml which creates a portal without any parent ref, then a new context is created and the virtual-host and context path settings of the war file is bound to it. The id of the context is either the application name given by jboss-app.xml or derived from the virtual-host and context path. I haven't updated Transient PortalObjectContainer yet with the new functionality, just added the method declarations to make it compile.

Next, after the deployment had been taken care of, the request processing had to change slightly. The servername is fetched from the request in PortalServlet and stored in ServletRequestContext. The CommandFactory classes are updated so that doMapping gets the portalHost parameter.

DefaultPortalCommandFactory caused a strange behaviour, if a link was wrong, e.g. spelled wrong or so, then it sent the request to the default portal. That resulted in that suddenly the default portal markup could appear in a middle of a page. I changed that so that if the CommandFactory chain failed to map the request, then a 404 response is sent via the new class ErrorResponseCommand. However, this more or less obsoletes this class. Instead CoreController should create a ErrorResponseCommand if cmd is null after passing through the CommandFactory chain.

DelegatingCommandFactoryService was modified to send a request to / to PortalObjectCommandFactory, it's doing that by shortcutting the PathParser but I think it's ok.

PortalObjectCommandFactory is modified to look up the context by using portalHost and portalContextPath. If a context can't be found using those data, then it tries to look up on just portalContextPath (for those cases where the webapp didn't specify any virual-host but just bind to the default name) and if still noting found then the default context is used.

CMSObjectCommandFactory was modified to send a ErrorResponseCommand with 404 if it couldn't find the file specified which is the correct behaviour. As it was before the default portal could suddenly appear in the middle of the page which looked quite strange. Also, it now respond with code 500 if an internal error occurs.

The same for StreamContentCommand. I noticed another thing, the file was first looked up in CMSObjectCommandFactory and then again in StreamContentCommand. I added a shortcut so that it could be passed along and hence eliminating the second lookup.

 A minor change had to be done on the security, in JACCPortalAuthorizationManager and JACCPortalAuthorizationManagerFactory as the configured roles have to be managed per context id (i.e. war file).

The last big change was on how theme is handled. Before it just rendered an url, e.g. /portal-core/themes/phalanx/portal_style.css which didnt work because that path didn't exsist in my virtual-host. Instead I created a new CommandFactory which is bound to /theme so if I have a portal bound to the url http://portaltest.abrahamsson.com which use theme Npalanx then the stylesheet is loaded from http://portaltest.abrahamsson.com/theme/themes/phalanx/portal_style.css 

Julien and Roy, please read through these proposed changes and let me know what you think.
column298:
13/Sep/06 6:35 PM;julien1;Looking at it quickly, you need to provide a solution that does not require modifications of the PortalObject concepts.

Why not map virtual host to portal instead ?

The PortalObject : Context is supposed to be unique and the root of the portal object tree.
column299:
13/Sep/06 7:54 PM;sverker;Well, the idea I had was that since a different web application is essentially a different context then create new contexts under the root would be the right way to go. If you have only one context then you can optimize it away, it doesn't add any value to the data model.

Not that it matters though, I think it should be possible to map ContextPath to Portal instead. The only issue I can think of from the top of my head is how to decide which is the default portal if several portals is deployed in the same *-object.xml without parent references but that can be handled by being a bit picky when deploying.

I don't really care which, the only thing I care about is the functionality in the end.
column300: 14/Sep/06 10:32 AM;sverker;I have uploaded a new patch which binds virtual hosts to the portal instead of context.
column301:
16/Sep/06 7:34 PM;sverker;I've done some more investigations and see that the first solution with separate contexts is the way to go. Why? Because isolation is needed between the applications.

With the implementation where the virtual-host/context-path information is bound to the Portal object then if I deploy my portal to http://portaltest.abrahamsson.com then I can access the default portal on http://portaltest.abrahamsson.com/portal/default/. Well, sort of since the portlets are rendered but images etc can't be loaded, since they are in a different web application context.

That is essentially the point, like the servlet container maintains different contexts to isolate different applications so does the portal server need to do. This turned out to work supprisingly well in the first approach I did, the rest of the app seams to be designed with multiple contexts in mind even if the model isn't.

What needs to be discussed is how it should be specified in the *-object.xml file which context a portal should be deployed to. I find that the most logical is that unless a parent ref is specified then it should be bound to the context created by the war. If the parent ref is empty (i.e. <parentref/>) then the portal is bound to the default context and if a specific parent is specified then the it is bound to that context. This is also consistent with how things have worked historically.

I've done some basic testing on letting the portals having different security domains which seams to work fine but needs further analysis, especially how it affects the cms.

Note that the ObjectNodes still form a tree, with the default context as root and the other contextes as children to it.
column302:
01/Jan/08 4:53 PM;dpocock;

What is the current status of this issue - is anyone working on a solution already?

I've been looking at the following use case/potential solution:
- a single JBoss server (or cluster of servers)
- Apache2 with mod_jk as the front end
- multiple `VirtualHost' definitions in Apache2
- each VirtualHost has a JkMount for /portal/* and /portal-core/*
- Each virtual site has it's own entry page, template, etc.  

However, there is no isolation between the sites - a user can construct a URL that let's them see content from any of the sites through any of the VirtualHosts.  This is a viable solution if all the sites are related.  If the sites are not related (e.g. if one site is for a mining company and another site is for an environment group), then such a solution would be inappropriate.

column1: User Specific Theme
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
It would be nice to associate a Theme to a particular user. 

1. Add a theme selection option for the User Profile.
2. When the user is created default this to default theme. 
3. When rendering use the user profile's theme to render the page if he is logged in.
4. If user is not logged in then use default theme to render.
column56:

Will update release version when Resolving the request;16/Jun/06 5:44 AM;mageshbk;57600
column293: 06/Jun/06 5:33 PM;scott.metz;If we are getting hung up on the concept of a Theme then maybe what we are really asking for is a "skin" support where skins are user specific and themes are still global.
column294: 07/Jun/06 3:50 PM;avoleti;Having a particular user skin change reflect globally across to all users creates a major support issue.  We need to have the skins user-specific
column295: 07/Jun/06 6:15 PM;danny_hon;This is what happens today in both JBP 2.2.x or 2.4.  Theme has an application scope rather than a session or user scope.  If user A changes the theme to theme X, all users will see theme X immediately.  If another user tries to change the theme to theme Y, all users will see theme Y (includes user A) immediately.  I consider this a bug.
column296:
09/Jun/06 1:08 PM;danny_hon;In step 2, instead of setting a default value when an user is created.  What about if the profile theme attribute is null for a particular user, then it will use the default theme?  This will not impact existing users in the portal.

Another point is if the theme is deleted afterwards, the users who selected the deleted theme before should use the default theme.

column1: Deal with non standard Locales better
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
Per the WSRP Spec regarding UnsupportedLocale fault:
The Portlet does not support generating markup for the requested locale. Since the Portlet is not required to generate markup in the requested locale, a Portlet returning this fault message is indicating that it processes locales in a stricter manner and has no markup for the requested locales. The Consumer can treat this as a specialization of the OperationFailed fault message and does not have to retry getting the markup in other locales.

Currently, LocaleInfo throws an IllegalArgumentException if the locale is not standard which gets wrapped into an OperationFailedFault at the handler level. We should deal with locale errors better and maybe be more lenient as to what we accept.

column1: Check WSRP type definition to check for non-nillable values
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
JBoss WS stack creates default value for nillable WSDL elements. If no valid value is provided for a non-nillable element, this will cause an error about elements being out of sequence.

Example:
From wsrp_v1_types.xsd, a valid markup request conforms to the getMarkup element:
registrationContext (nillable), portletContext, runtimeContext, userContext (nillable), markupParams.
runtimeContext is non-nillable. If no valid runtimeContext is provided when creating the getMarkup object, the WS stack will not emit an element for runtimeContext whereas one will be for userContext (which is nillable), resulting in the WS complaining about userContext not being in the right position in the sequence.
column56: Added WSRPTypeFactory to ensure that WSRP types are properly created. This will also be used for documentation purpose.;12/Apr/06 1:54 AM;claprun;3600

column1: When displaying a dir listing, a stacktrace is produced if no content can be found for the default language

column54: When the CMS list a directory, it tries to get the content for each file, this is actually not necessary since the content is not used. Still it tries to get the content for the default language. If there was no content for that default language, an ugly stack trace is displayed.

column1: CMS exception with PostgreSQL on startup
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
Exception:
org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: Large Objects may not be used in auto-commit mode.

raises on startup when using PostgreSQL
column293: 30/Mar/06 6:31 PM;claprun;I think we've seen that problem in a different context and a fix exists. However, I don't remember what it is. There might be a forum post and/or wiki page related to this issue.
column294: 30/Mar/06 6:35 PM;claprun;Possible related issue and solution: http://jira.jboss.com/jira/browse/JBPORTAL-575?decorator=printable
column295:
31/Mar/06 4:03 AM;theute;Fixed.
There are 2 things to be careful when using PostgreSQL

* BLOB must be accessed in a transaction
* InputStream must be closed *before* commiting the transaction

(Thanks Chris and Roy for your hints)

column1: "Cannot get content" error when editing a file in different locale than the user's default language set in the profile

column54:
I found this error when attempting ot edit index.html in CMS Manager, here are the steps to get the exception

1. log in as admin and modify your profile's language to anything other than English (mine was set to Bulgarian).
2. go to CMS Manager and click on default and open index.html (this would work with any html files you might have in your CMS)
3. click the "edit" icon.
this is the link that is generated by the click, showing the file's locale in EN
http://localhost:8080/portal/auth/portal/default/CMS%20Manager/CMSAdminPortletWindow?op=edit&path=%2Fdefault%2Findex.html&mask=2&language=en&version=1.0

column1: Changing the mime type at the porlet level has no effect
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54: Changing the content type of a content in the Admin portlet CMS (or any end-user portlet using the CMS) has no effect since the CMS command is deciding itself.
column56: Resolved, if the mime type has not been defined, the CMS command picks one depending on the file extension, otherwise it just uses the one specified.;29/Mar/06 4:42 AM;theute;3600

column1: Creating files with no extension using the editor are not editable
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
When a user create a file with unknown extension using the editor, it was falling back to "application/octet-stream" and made that file non editable anymore.

It should default to "text/plain"
column293: 06/Apr/06 6:46 PM;rali;I verified this works now, but if you click the Edit button on this same "unknown extension" file and edit it, although the initial version was "text/plain", the new version goes back to "application/octet-stream". This version is still editable under the WYSIWYG editor, just the field "type" is wrong.

column1: Portlet Specification 1.0 API test cases
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
Implement test cases for javax.portlet.* classes - Portlet Specification 1.0 API. 
Test cases should not double assertions already done in:
Portlet Specification 1.0 "PLT.F TCK Assertions" - (http://jira.jboss.com/jira/browse/JBPORTAL-636)
Portlet Container test cases beyond "PLT.F TCK Assertions" - (http://jira.jboss.com/jira/browse/JBPORTAL-637)

This test should assert API contracts like - 'null' argument - IllegalArgumentException is thrown. All implementation or behavioral tests should be done in EXT part (http://jira.jboss.com/jira/browse/JBPORTAL-637)

column1: Verify portal 2.4 on Branch 4.0 on windows
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
Please verify that the build from Branch 4.0  (ie. jboss-4.0.4.CR2) has no issues for portal 2.4

Check that the portal deploys without any errors and you can access the portal.

column293:
17/Mar/06 6:11 PM;anil.saldhana;How to build jboss-portal-2.4
=========================
cvs co jboss-portal-2.4
cd jboss-portal-2.4/build
ant 



How to build Branch_4_0
====================
cvs co -r Branch_4_0 jboss-4.0.x 
cd jboss-4.0.x/build
./build.sh
or
build 

The built jboss version should be in jboss-4.0.x/build/output/jboss-4.0.4.CR2 


Bolek asked for this information.

column1: Hardcoded PortalDS prevent to use another ds
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
I changed build/local.properties the default JNDI name of the database to DefaultDS instead of PortalDS

The generated files are ok, they call contain references to DefaultDS in the embedded jackrabbit file of the jboss-service.xml of the cms sar.

I deploy the portal with the CMS and the CMS service tries to use PortalDS in one of its hibernate store during the hibernate factories configuration.

When debugging the CMS to find out from where that PortalDS comes I noticed that :

1/ the hibernate store receive a PortalDS from the jackrabbit configuration layer
2/ the file extracted from the jboss-service.xml contains all refs to DefaultDS
column293:
04/Apr/06 6:24 AM;theute;It is not hardcoded, what happened is that at the first start, JackRabbit stores the workspaces configuration in DefaultDS then reuse that one on other startups instead of the new one provided in jboss-services.xml

To get rid of that problem it's enough to delete: server/xxx/data/portal/cms/conf/workspaces/default/workspace.xml


That said, i am checking why and how this is stored to avoid that kind of problem
column294: 04/Apr/06 6:40 AM;theute;Not in Default DS sorry but in the data directory.
column295:
04/Apr/06 7:12 AM;theute;So the Workspace definition is written once in the home directory when it is created by Jackrabbit.

Note: We could save that file in the database (Configuration repository but this wouldn't help us, on the opposite it would be even more painful to remove on a single machine. On a cluster it would be easier though)
column296: 04/Apr/06 7:42 AM;julien1;thanks for the info, I think that as long as it is documented and that the information in that repository is identical on all nodes on a cluster then it is a better solution to leave it as is.
column297: 04/Apr/06 7:46 AM;julien1;you can resolve this case by adding that in the documentation.
column298: 04/Apr/06 8:03 AM;theute;This is mostly a matter of documentation. Will see with Jackrabbit the reasons for this.

column294:
28/Feb/06 12:09 AM;anil.saldhana;Steps are: 
1) Copy the jboss-portal.sar from core/output/lib to jboss-4.0.4rc1 deploy dir
2) Copy the jbossws14.sar from thirdparty/jboss-jbossws14/lib to deploy dir.
3) Remove the jboss-ws4ee.sar from the deploy dir.
4) Copy retrotranslator-runtime.jar from thirdparty/retro....   to /server/default/lib
   of your 4.0.4rc1 distro.
5) Copy backport-util-concurrent.jar (from this JIRA issue)  into the /server/default/lib directory.
6) Go to wsrp module and do "ant test"

column56:
- test cases implementation
- some issues with interpretation of the spec and unexpected by me portal behaviour;19/Feb/06 5:00 PM;bdaw;7200
column293:
19/Feb/06 5:04 PM;bdaw;implemented and commited in cvs - but test case is commented out in code.

As writen in spec:

SPEC:17 Testable= true Section=PLT.5.2.4.4:
A PortletException signals that an error has occurred during the processing of the request and that the portlet container should take appropriate measures to clean up the request. If a portlet throws an exception in the processAction method, all operations on the ActionResponse must be ignored and the render method must not be invoked within the current client request

What is unclear - if one portlet throws PortletException in processAction() should other portlets on page be rendered()?

Currently in JBoss Portal when one portlet throws PortletException http code "500" is returned. This behaviour should be configurable by admin

SPEC:7 Testable=true Section=PLT.5.2.2.1
The portlet container may reattempt to instantiate and initialize the portlets at any time after a failure. The exception to this rule is when an UnavailableException indicates a minimum time of unavailability. When this happens the portlet container must wait for the specified time to pass before creating and initializing a new portlet object.

What will be the best approach to test it using current testframework abilities?

The exception to this rule is when an UnavailableException indicates a minimum time of unavailability. When this happens the portlet container must wait for the specified time to pass before creating and initializing a new portlet object.

But it doesn't seem to be much testable using current testsuite....

column293:
17/Mar/06 3:36 PM;bdaw;Security is not testable with current test framework, so this issue is posponed for now

This chapter contains few assertions that shoud be tested later: 

SPEC:151 Testable=true Section= PLT.20.4
The values that the Portlet API getRemoteUser and getUserPrincipal methods return the same values returned by the equivalent methods of the servlet response object
NOT TESTABLE WITH CURRENT FRAMEWORK - POSTPONED

clii SPEC:152 Testable=true Section= PLT.20.4
The isUserInRole method expects a string parameter with the role-name. A security-role-ref element must be declared by the portlet in deployment descriptor with a role-name sub-element containing the role-name to be passed to the method. The security-role-ref element should contain a role-link sub-element whose value is the name of the application security role that the user may be mapped into. This mapping is specified in the web.xml deployment descriptor file. The container uses the mapping of security-role-ref to security-role when determining the return value of the call.
NOT TESTABLE WITH CURRENT FRAMEWORK - POSTPONED

cliii SPEC:153 Testable=true Section= PLT.20.4
If the security-role-ref element does not define a role-link element, the container must default to checking the role-name element argument against the list of securityrole elements defined in the web.xml deployment descriptor of the portlet application.
NOT TESTABLE WITH CURRENT FRAMEWORK - POSTPONED

There are also two 'Propagation of Security Identity in EJBTM Calls' assertions but there is no need to test it now.

column1: Spring Portal Integration - JBPortal not following JSR168 for getPortletMode on an Action?
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
I can view all the pages in the books sample portlet without any problems. The issue occurs with I submit any of the forms (edit book details, add new book) in this example, or click on any of the ?update? icons (from book inventory, Increase count, descrease count, or delete book). When I submit any of these actions I get the following exception:

15:10:50,149 ERROR [InvokeWindowActionCommand] An portlet exception occured in portlet /spring-portlet-sample.books
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.jboss.portal.portlet.impl.ActionRequestImpl.getPortletMode(ActionRequestImpl.java:45)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.FrameworkPortlet.processRequest(FrameworkPortlet.java:448)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.FrameworkPortlet.processAction(FrameworkPortlet.java:399)
	at org.jboss.portal.portlet.PortletContainer.invokeAction(PortletContainer.java:470)
	at org.jboss.portal.portlet.PortletContainer.dispatch(PortletContainer.java:411)
	at org.jboss.portal.server.app.ComponentInvocation.dispatch(ComponentInvocation.java:66)
....

From the Spring Portal lead:

Unfortunately, this looks like a bug in JBoss Portal. Based on your stack trace, it looks like they are throwing an exception when we try to call getPortletMode on an ActionRequest -- this is line with the JSR-168 Spec. Please report this issue to JBoss so that they can correct it on their end.

I've beefed up the code in FrameworkPortlet to catch this exception and simply not include the portlet mode in the application event if it's not available.

This is in JIRA entry SPR-1582: http://opensource2.atlassian.com/projects/spring/browse/SPR-1582
column55:
JBoss AS 4.0.3SP1 with JBoss Portal 2.2
Sun Java 1.5.0_05
Spring 2.0m1
Spring-portlet-sample from http://opensource2.atlassian.com/confluence/spring/pages/viewpageattachments.action?pageId=10
column293: 29/Dec/05 3:04 PM;sgwood;The Spring Portal example configured for JBoss Portal
column294:
01/Jan/06 1:10 PM;sgwood;
Another NPE in JBoss:

2005-12-31 04:49:52,171 WARN  [org.springframework.web.portlet.DispatcherPortlet] Handler execution resulted in exception - forwarding to resolved error view
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.jboss.portal.portlet.impl.ActionRequestImpl.getPortletMode(ActionRequestImpl.java:45)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.handler.PortletModeParameterHandlerMapping.getHandlerInternal(PortletModeParameterHandlerMapping.java:245)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.handler.AbstractHandlerMapping.getHandler(AbstractHandlerMapping.java:94)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.DispatcherPortlet.getHandler(DispatcherPortlet.java:715)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.DispatcherPortlet.doActionService(DispatcherPortlet.java:528)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.FrameworkPortlet.processRequest(FrameworkPortlet.java:416)
	at org.springframework.web.portlet.FrameworkPortlet.processAction(FrameworkPortlet.java:399)
	at org.jboss.portal.portlet.PortletContainer.invokeAction(PortletContainer.java:470)

From the Spring Portal developer:

Well, there's not much we can do about that one. This is happening when the PortletModeParameterHandlerMapping tries to determine the portlet mode. Since this is essential to its function, the Exception is appropriate. I'm afraid you will need to take this up with the JBoss Portal gang.
column295: 17/Jan/06 7:55 AM;juhana;It seems to me that the CanonicalCommandMapper adds a null Mode object if there isn't one specified by the "ctrl:mode" URL parameter, which can be set either directly with the <portlet:param> tag or as the "portletMode" attribute of the <portlet:actionURL> tag. As per JSR-168 the portletMode attribute is optional, it seems to me that either CanonicalCommandMapper or the tag handler implementation must be fixed to add a proper mode if none is specified explicitly.

column1: LDAP implementation of UserModule and RoleModule
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column293:
10/Nov/05 8:10 AM;julien1;To install, some other configurations must be made.

1) Open standardjboss-portlet.xml to change Portlet configuration interceptor org.jboss.portal.portlet.invocation.DispatcherInterceptor to use the classes org.jboss.portal.core.impl.user.MSADActionRequest and org.jboss.portal.core.impl.user.MSADRenderRequest for action and render requests respectively.

2)Change META-INF/jboss-service.xml to configure UserModule and RoleModule mbeans.
example:
  <mbean
     code="org.jboss.portal.core.impl.user.MSADUserModule"
     name="portal:service=Module,type=User"
     xmbean-dd="org/jboss/portal/core/impl/user/MSADUserModule.xml">
     <depends>portal:service=Hibernate</depends>
     <attribute name="JNDIName">java:portal/UserModule</attribute>
     <attribute name="domain">msaddomain.com</attribute>
     <attribute name="user">ldap_search_user</attribute>
     <attribute name="password">#$%</attribute>
  </mbean>
  <mbean
     code="org.jboss.portal.core.impl.role.MSADRoleModule"
     name="portal:service=Module,type=Role"
     xmbean-dd="org/jboss/portal/core/impl/role/MSADRoleModule.xml">
     <depends>portal:service=Hibernate</depends>
     <attribute name="JNDIName">java:portal/RoleModule</attribute>
     <attribute name="domain">msaddomain.com</attribute>
     <attribute name="user">ldap_search_user</attribute>
     <attribute name="password">#$%</attribute>
  </mbean>
3)Change \portal-server.war\WEB-INF\web.xml to configure JBossSecurityFilter as follow
  <filter>
     <filter-name>JbossSecurityFilter</filter-name>
     <filter-class>org.jboss.portal.core.security.jaas.servletfilter.JbossSecurityFilter</filter-class>
   <init-param>
       <param-name>securityManagerName</param-name>
       <param-value>java:jaas/portal</param-value>
   </init-param>
  </filter>
  <filter-mapping>
     <filter-name>JbossSecurityFilter</filter-name>
     <servlet-name>PortalServlet</servlet-name>
  </filter-mapping>
this filter makes a request wrapper that gets user and role information from the JaasSecurityManager.
column294:
03/Feb/06 12:22 PM;julien1;Here is the configuration that must be done in jboss-service.xml.

  <mbean
     code="org.jboss.portal.core.impl.user.MSADUserModule"
     name="portal:service=Module,type=User"
     xmbean-dd="org/jboss/portal/core/impl/user/MSADUserModule.xml">
     <depends optional-attribute-name="HibernateProvider" proxy-type="attribute">portal:service=Hibernate</depends>
     <attribute name="JNDIName">java:portal/UserModule</attribute>
     <attribute name="domain">sjes.com.br</attribute>
     <attribute name="user">administrator</attribute>
     <attribute name="password">****</attribute>
     <attribute name="IDAttribute">objectGUID</attribute>
     <attribute name="userNameAttribute">sAMAccountName</attribute>
     <attribute name="displayNameAttribute">displayName</attribute>
     <attribute name="mailAttribute">mail</attribute>
     <attribute name="filter"><![CDATA[(&(objectClass=user)(SAMAccountName=jes*))]]></attribute>
     <attribute name="orderBy">displayName</attribute>
     <attribute name="ldapSecure">true</attribute>
  </mbean>
  <mbean
     code="org.jboss.portal.core.impl.role.MSADRoleModule"
     name="portal:service=Module,type=Role"
     xmbean-dd="org/jboss/portal/core/impl/role/MSADRoleModule.xml">
     <depends>portal:service=Hibernate</depends>
     <attribute name="JNDIName">java:portal/RoleModule</attribute>
     <attribute name="domain">sjes.com.br</attribute>
     <attribute name="user">administrator</attribute>
     <attribute name="password">***</attribute>
     <attribute name="IDAttribute">objectGUID</attribute>
     <attribute name="nameAttribute">name</attribute>
     <attribute name="displayNameAttribute">displayName</attribute>
     <attribute name="filter"><![CDATA[(objectClass=group)]]></attribute>
     <attribute name="orderBy">displayName</attribute>
     <attribute name="baseDN">OU=Servicos,DC=SJES,DC=COM,DC=BR</attribute>
     <attribute name="ldapSecure">true</attribute>
  </mbean>

column54:
create/reply posts works. But deletion of posts failed.

It is suspected that the foreign key constrains for jbp_forums_topics table and jbp_forums_posts are not defined properly. 
The foreign key reference is bi-directional. Is this correct? Following is the database schema for postgresql.

bossportal=# \d jbp_forums_posts

Column | Type | Modifiers
-----------------+-----------------------------+-----------
jbp_id | integer | not null
jbp_topic_id | integer |
jbp_edit_count | integer |
jbp_edit_date | timestamp without time zone |
jbp_create_date | timestamp without time zone |
jbp_subject | character varying(255) |
jbp_text | character varying(255) |
jbp_poster_id | integer |

"jbp_forums_posts_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (jbp_id)

"fkf2c0436dbfb64ffa" FOREIGN KEY (jbp_topic_id) REFERENCES jbp_forums_topics(jbp_id)

column56:
The mappings are as they were. When I tried to change it to one-to-one there were additional problems and it seems that they are correct. 
There were no problems with deleting "middle" post. Only when deleting post to which there is reference in topic.lastPost or topic.fistPost properties there is foreign key constrain error. It's strange as there is cascade="none" set in mappings. 

What I did is some corrections in DeletePostCommand.java (set last/first post to null in topic before removal) and in ForumsModuleImpl.java (session.flush() before post/topic delete). 

It's not beautiful but in future lastPost and firstPost will be replaced: http://jira.jboss.com/jira/browse/JBPORTAL-336;31/Jul/05 11:48 AM;bdaw;43200

column1: Forum Emails Not Sent on Watched Forums
column11: JBoss Portal is the next generation open source portal framework from JBoss. It is entirely standards-based and supports the JSR-168 Portlet specification, which allows you to easily plug-in standards-compliant modules to meet your specific Portal needs.
column54:
To reproduce:

1. Configure the mail server on localhost (i.e., sendmail)
2.  Configure jboss portal 2.0 with a deployed Forums portlet configured to connect to send to 'localhost', no user, no passwd.
3.  Login using a authenticated user to the portal
4. Choose a forum that is deployed on JBP2.0 and "watch" that forum
5.  Post a test message
6.  No message is ever received, nothing in the logs, no exceptions

When trying to reproduce this problem, I can show you on our labs servers that forum emails do not work.  We've implemented other email services, outside of forums, and they *do* work.  But, for some reason, forums isn't sending out emails.
column56:
- set up linux box with postfix
- deployed portal from jbp 2.0 branch on jboss AS 4.0.2 with mails debug enabled in jboss-service.xml
- tested watched topics and replies for users posts mails notification

All seems to work fine. Mails are recieved and SMTP connection syntax looks ok in logs.;04/Aug/05 1:48 PM;bdaw;28800
column293:
30/Jul/05 5:55 AM;yxyang;But it works on my system and you can try at www.mobmeee.com. 

(1)You need to change the ./core/src/resources/portal-core-sar/META-INF/jboss-service.xml as following and enable the debug information and make sure your sendmail service is running (on port 25)

   <mbean
      code="org.jboss.portal.core.impl.mail.MailModuleImpl"
      name="portal:service=Module,type=Mail"
      xmbean-dd="org/jboss/portal/core/impl/mail/MailModuleImpl.xml">
      <!--depends>jboss:service=Mail</depends-->
      <depends>portal:service=Module,type=User</depends>
      <attribute name="QueueCapacity">-1</attribute>
      <attribute name="Gateway">localhost</attribute>
      <attribute name="SmtpUser"></attribute>
      <attribute name="SmtpPassword"></attribute>
      <attribute name="JavaMailDebugEnabled">true</attribute>
      <attribute name="SMTPConnectionTimeout">100000</attribute>
      <attribute name="SMTPTimeout">10000</attribute>
      <attribute name="JNDIName">java:portal/MailModule</attribute>
   </mbean>

(2)In addition, of course, you need to edit your profile properly so that your email is there.
(3)modify your ./src/resources/portal-forums-war/WEB-INF/portlet.xml file: (Like my configuration)
      <init-param>
         <description>Email address used for FROM field of email notification</description>
         <name>fromAddress</name>
         <value>support@mobmeee.com</value>
      </init-param>

And make sure the server running the forum has the same domain name as the  domain name of "<value>support@mobmeee.com</value>", because some configurations of SMTP will reject to relay.
column294: 08/Aug/05 4:38 PM;bdaw;Mails tested and working. If there are problems just enable mail debug like Yang posted in comment for this issue. In debug mode all SMTP connections are logged so it's very easy to find out what is going on with our emails....

column1: Problem with fork/join using swimlane
column11: jBPM is a flexible business process management suite.
column54:
INFO: exception while executing command org.jbpm.pvm.internal.cmd.CompositeCmd@1175881
org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not delete: [org.jbpm.pvm.internal.task.SwimlaneImpl#280142]


<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<process name="test" xmlns="http://jbpm.org/4.0/jpdl">
   
   <swimlane candidate-groups="A" name="A"/>

   <swimlane candidate-groups="B" name="B"/>
            
   <start name="start">
      <transition to="task1A"/>
   </start>

   <task name="task1A" swimlane="A">
      <transition to="task1B"/>
   </task>

   <task name="task1B" swimlane="B">
      <transition to="fork"/>
   </task>

   <fork name="fork">
      <transition to="task2A"/>
      <transition to="task2B"/>
   </fork>

   <task name="task2A" swimlane="A">
      <transition to="join"/>
   </task>

   <task name="task2B" swimlane="B">
      <transition to="join"/>
   </task>


   <join name="join">
      <transition to="end"/>
   </join>

   <end name="end"/>

</process>
column288: Make the join async by adding: continue="async" to the join element
