column1: Farm deploy of large EAR doesn't replicate to other cluster node
column11: A cross cutting project encompassing clustering issues related to common clustering utilities and clustering layer integration.
column54: I setup a two node JBoss cluster (either same machine or two different machines) and copy a large ear (22,725,139 byte file) into the farm deploy folder.  The file doesn't replicate to the other server instance farm folder.  I have seen an outOfMemory exception occur but increasing Java memory makes that go away, however, the EAR still doesn't replicate to the other node.
column56:
Spent two hours getting my development environment setup this morning.  Took me a while to figure out that I need to do chmod 777 tools/bin/ant in order for the ./build/build.sh to work.

Spent a few hours reading code, adding some debug prints and finally running with the jdb debugger.

Found workaround, increase Java memory:  export JAVA_OPTS="-Xmx512m";22/Apr/05 1:53 PM;smarlow;14400
column293:
22/Apr/05 1:30 PM;smarlow;According to the Java debugger (jdb), the java.lang.OutOfMemoryError occurs when we try to create a byte array for the size of the deployment archive.

The ScannerThread[1] where
  [1] java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream.toByteArray (ByteArrayOutputStream.java:136)
  [2] org.jboss.ha.framework.server.FarmMemberService.getFileContent (FarmMemberService.java:337)
  [3] org.jboss.ha.framework.server.FarmMemberService.deploy (FarmMemberService.java:401)
  [4] org.jboss.deployment.scanner.URLDeploymentScanner.scan (URLDeploymentScanner.java:485)
  [5] org.jboss.deployment.scanner.AbstractDeploymentScanner$ScannerThread.doScan (AbstractDeploymentScanner.java:198)
  [6] org.jboss.deployment.scanner.AbstractDeploymentScanner$ScannerThread.loop (AbstractDeploymentScanner.java:209)
  [7] org.jboss.deployment.scanner.AbstractDeploymentScanner$ScannerThread.run (AbstractDeploymentScanner.java:188)
ScannerThread[1]
column294:
22/Apr/05 2:02 PM;smarlow;I tried to see if I could workaround the problem by increasing the max java memory on both cluster nodes.

From both shell scripts, I set the java options for JBoss as follows:

 export JAVA_OPTS="-Xmx512m"

The farm deploy worked (make sure that you increase memory on each cluster node).

A better solution would be to farm deploy in smaller chunks (stream).

We could send 64k blocks at a time with 1 of N numbering.

Perhaps this work could be combined with making farm deployment atomic as we would need a graceful way to handle failure in case the originator stops sending blocks before the last block is sent.
column295: 23/Apr/05 3:08 PM;ben.wang;I don't under why replicating a 22MB chunk will require a 512MB heap though? DO you have any idea?
column296:
26/Apr/05 11:32 AM;smarlow;I don't know that we actually need a 512M heap.  We probably need more than the default of 128M but perhaps less than 512M.

The problem was only reported to occur on Linux and not Windows.  I checked the Win32 run.bat and we set max Java memory to 512m by default.  On Linux, we set max Java memory to 128m.
column297:
27/May/05 4:30 AM;garu;Hi Scott,
i was hit by the same problem, and i've experimented a bit with farm deployment. I crafted a solution that is farming application files transferring chunks of data, whose size may be chosen with an attribute.
It is not production code, it's just what it is, an experiment, but it's working and may give you some ideas about.
A word of caution, i had to setup a thread for file transfer when farmDeploy() is called from remote because it must return before the first getFileChunk() request goes to the farmDeploy() caller otherwise getFileChunk() request will never get an answer and everything will lock.
I have traced the thing and it looks that i cannot get an answer from a node that sent me a request until i answer that request.
Jgoups limitation? May be it's worth investigating.
column298:
14/Jun/05 11:50 AM;smarlow;Jira issues JBCLUSTER-33 + JBAS-1899 are solved with this change.
Previously, when farm deploying an application archive we read the entire file into memory and passed as an RPC parameter.  With this code change, we instead read in up to 512K bytes at a time and pass as an RPC parameter.

The following changes are checked into 4.0.3 (will check into head next):
org.jboss.ha.framework.interfaces.ClusterNode - made Serializable so I could pass it on RPC.
org.jboss.ha.framework.server.ClusterFileTransfer - handles transfering of files on the cluster.
org.jboss.ha.framework.server.FarmMemberService - updated to use ClusterFileTransfer.
org.jboss.ha.framework.interfaces.HAPartition - added method to return current ClusterNode.
org.jboss.ha.framework.server.HAPartitionImpl - implement method to return current ClusterNode.
org.jboss.ha.framework.server.FarmMemberServiceMBean - removed FileContent class.

column1: Tutorial - GUI/beanshell block if node modified within transaction and node status queried via GUI
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
Instructions:
- add a node to the cache
- start a transaction
- do a put on that node
- clicking on the node via the GUI to check that the node has not been 
updated blocks both the GUI and the beanshell. This is due to not being able to 
acquire the read lock on the node to show it.
- Also, once the exception is thrown, the GUI/beanshell stops which shouldn't.

Solution:
- Updates on the GUI should be handled in a different thread so that it does 
not block the shell? While the shell is blocked, the current transaction cannot be 
committed, leaving the user no option.
column293:
02/May/07 5:18 AM;galder.zamarreno;Manik, I'm working refactoring the tutorial to fit PojoCache tutorial into it too, 
so I might as well deal with this JIRA too?
column294:
18/May/07 3:41 PM;galder.zamarreno;GUI updates originating from clicking on nodes in the tree structure and 
mouse clicks are now handled in a separate thread to avoid locking the GUI. 
TimeoutExceptions that could be thrown from these code areas provide a 
hint on what might the cause of the exception.

column1: Create Transforming CacheLoaders that transform 1.x formatted data into 2.x format
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
Customers that want to use JBossCache 2.x might be reluctant to 
migrate their data from one format to the other. I can see how an 
existing customer might think this is a proper pain in the ass, 
independent of the benefits, and might reduce adoption among them.

We want to remove barriers upgrading, but at the same time, we want 
new customer to use new marshalling, so I'd actually implement the 
possibility to use 1.x marshalling which is plan java serialization at 
the CacheLoader level. This could easily achieved adding a property to 
the <properties> section.

The default in 2.x should be to use VAM and only people who are 
resilient to change their existing stores to VAM should use the 1.x 
option, which would need explicitly definition.

This option also makes it easier for migration purpouses as customers 
should be able to start two cache instances with different cache loader 
marshalling method set. They could then loop through the first one using 
get operations and call put in the second instance.

Just note that this does not apply to the marshalling done at 
replication level as there's no hard data that needs migrating.
column293:
07/Mar/07 5:57 PM;galder.zamarreno;A completely new approach is being implemented now:

"After discussions with Brian we came up with a different approach for this.

My previous approach (don't need to read all below) relied on introducing legacy code into the main source code that would be able to read 1.x serialization. As I started doing it, I realised that it would need a lot of changes and it would clutter the 2.0 codebase.

Instead, with the help of Brian, we came up with a different idea, which is creating two one-off cache loaders, TransformingJDBCCacheLoader and TransformingFileCacheLoader. They extend the existing cache loaders, but they differentiate by unmarshall stuff in the 1.x way.

This way, we have cache loaders that can read in 1.x way and write in 2.x way. Now, a customer just needs to write a program that uses a cache configured to use any of these two cache loaders above and all it has to do is loop through the tree reading all nodes and putting them back, and voila! you have your data store format changed (I'll be writing an example of this).

It's a pretty clean solution to transforming data without making changes to main o.j.cache tree.

But, there's always a but :) , 1.4.x used org.jboss.invocation.MarshalledValue so there's no way of getting around the need of having this class to do this. This is because JDBCCacheLoader stored instances of MarshalledValue, so even the MV class in AOP would not work cos it's a different package (it'd result in CCE)

One thing Brian suggested is that these two cache loaders and jboss-minimal are kept in a separate dir structure to the main one and when we distribute, we provide an extra jar containing these that can be used to transform data and that's it. After that, you get rid of it, you go back to the standard libraries.

It's pretty hard to find a neater way of dealing with this but the benefits are worth it, customer's data stays alive! "
column294:
07/Mar/07 6:31 PM;galder.zamarreno;I'm gonna commit the first part of the work:

- Transforming Cache Loaders implemented and unit tests provided
- Structure created:
[JBC-SOURCE-ROOT]
  + migration
    + src
      + o.j.c.migration.TransformingJDBCCacheLoader
      + o.j.c.migration.TransformingFileCacheLoader
      + o.j.c.migration.LegacyJDBCCacheLoader (JDBCCacheLoaderOld)

column1: Creating a custom cache loader which delegates to a standard cache loader, can generate misleading WARN messages
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
FileCacheLoader can return a null value for get(fqn) if the node does not exist.

 /**
    * Returns all keys and values from the persistent store, given a fully qualified name.
    *
    * NOTE that the expected return value of this method has changed from JBossCache 1.2.x
    * and before!  This will affect cache loaders written prior to JBossCache 1.3.0 and such
    * implementations should be checked for compliance with the behaviour expected.
    *
    * @param name
    * @return Map<Object,Object> keys and values for the given node. Returns
    * null if the node is not found.  If the node is found but has no
    * attributes, this method returns an empty Map.
    * @throws Exception
 */

If the customer creates a custom cache loader which delegates to a FileCacheLoader, the 
following misleading warning message is logged:

10:52:10.839 WARN [MessageListenerThread - Belvedere/Desk/CacheLoaderInterceptor] CacheLoader.get(Fqn) returned a null; assuming the node nodes not exist.
10:52:10.839 WARN [MessageListenerThread - Belvedere/Desk/CacheLoaderInterceptor] The CacheLoader interface has changed since JBossCache 1.3.x
10:52:10.839 WARN [MessageListenerThread - Belvedere/Desk/CacheLoaderInterceptor] Please see http://jira.jboss.com/jira/browse/JBCACHE-118
10:52:10.849 WARN [MessageListenerThread - Belvedere/Desk/CacheLoaderInterceptor] CacheLoader.get() should return an empty Map if the node does exist but doesn't have any attributes.

This occurrs even though the FileCacheLoader is actually doing the job accordingly.
column293:
26/Sep/06 4:19 AM;galder.zamarreno;Update the case comment and title due to misunderstanding of the javadoc.
FileCacheLoader fullfills the javadoc, but in the special occasion of having a custom

would be log thinking that the newly create custom cache loader is breaking the contract.

column1: EvictionPolicyProvider WARN message is noisy and misleading
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
JBoss AS 4.0.x assumes JBossCache 1.2.x which originally used EvictionPolicyProvider 
variable to hold eviction policies. The usage of this variable has been deprecated, but 
JBossCache 1.3.x and 1.4.x still need to set it in order to provide backwards compatibility.

Calling setEvictionPolicyProvider() results on a misleading noisy WARN message, which :

"Using deprecated configuration element 'EvictionPolicyProvider'.  This is only provided 
for 1.2.x backward compatibility and may disappear in future releases."

This message should be downgraded and the text revised.

column1: Invalidation fails with region based marshalling enabled
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
Invalidation requires making a remote _evict command.  This fails with region-based marshalling enabled because TreeCacheMarshaller140 doesn't know how to extract the Fqn from the evict methods.

A simple fix is to include the evict methods in MethodDeclarations.crud_methods.  If for some reason that's no good, the methods can be specially handled in TreeCacheMarshaller140.extractFqnAsString()

P.S. : All these operations(i.e. delete, rename etc...) were tried out when the TreeCache service, JBoss etc... were shutdown, so this is not a issue of the files/folders being in use by some other process
column293:
26/May/06 8:46 AM;manik;The file cache loader stores each node as a separate file on disk.  Each node is stored in a file with the node name as the file name.  As such , depending on how the node is named, you may see problems on certain filesystems.

Your example shows Hibernate's naming convention when storing cached objects.  If you look at the contents of the tree cache, this is how Hibernate names nodes.  

This is not a bug in the FileCacheLoader but more a bug in naming conventions used.  Also, I would not recommend using the FileCacheLoader in production.

column1: Race condition with 2-PC and pessimistic locking
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
- This issue is relevant for REPL_SYNC mode, (default) isolation level REPEATABLE_READ, SyncCommitPhase (two-phase-commit) and PESSIMISTIC locking.
- Two caches: SrcCache is the one where we put the modifications, DstCache only receives the replicated modifications.
- Two threads (resp. transactions) A and B modifying the same node X concurrently on SrcCache.
- Let's assume the transaction A is faster in aquiring the lock on X.
- Transaction A modifies the node X and starts committing: local prepare, remote prepare, local commit. The remote prepare will lock the X on DstCache and it will stay locked until the remote commit releases it later. Note that in JBossCache 1.3.0SP1 the transaction will (at least as I see) release the lock on SrcCache immediately after the local commit step and before the remote (sync.) commit. It seems that this have changed between 1.2.4 and 1.3.0 releases.
- As soon as the lock on SrcCache is released by A, transaction B aquires the lock immediately and starts local modifications. Note that in some cases B is fast enough to do the local prepare and send a remote prepare message before the remote commit message of A. B is able to do this because the lock is released by A before its remote commit call.
- Now, we have the X locked by the remote prepare of A on DstCache, and waiting for the remote commit of A to release it. The next messages from SrcCache are in the following order coming up the JGROUPS stack of the DstCache: remote prepare for B, remote commit for A.
- The remote prepare of B blocks on DstCache, trying to acquire the lock still held by A.
- The remote commit of A waits in the UP queue of the STATE_TRANSFER, waiting for the previous message (which is the remote prepare of B) to be processed.
- So A cannot be committed because it's blocked by B, which cannot be prepared, because it's blocked by A, which cannot be committed and so on. Of course the result is a TimeoutException..."
column288:
This still works with optimistic locking, although concurrent transactions may be forced to roll backif they are unable to be validated.  

Other workarounds:

- Use async replication
column293: 05/May/06 10:41 AM;manik;Fix involves patching the ReplicationInterceptor

column1: prepare methodcall has a bigger payload size
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54: When work on JBCACHE-501, I have discovered the payload size when runnign udner tx, is bigger than 1.3. Need to find out why? Is MethodCall for prepare not properly covered?
column293: 03/May/06 11:23 PM;ben.wang;Look at the JBCACHE-501 comment 28/Apr/06 08:01 AM.
column294:
04/May/06 8:46 AM;manik;Fixed.  It was not bigger than 1.3 though, but still pretty big.  The test I used - org.jboss.cache.replication.SyncReplTxTest.testSyncRepl() - produced the following with 1.3.0 codebase:

prepare call: 820 bytes
commit call: 326 bytes

With the 1.4.0 codebase *before* this fix:

prepare call: 665 bytes
commit call: 34 bytes

So still a lot better than the 1.3.0 codebase (esp. the commit call) but not a huge saving on the prepare call.

After this fix, the prepare call is now almost a third of it's size:

prepare call: 247 bytes
commit call: 34 bytes

The reason for this anomaly is that the prepare call passes in a List of MethodCalls as a parameter.  The marshaller did not handle lists in any special way so it identified the parameter as a list and proceeded to serialize the entire list without looking at its contents.

Lists are now handled specially, with its own magic number so the list itself is never serialized, just the contents, using EnhancedTreeCacheMarshaller.marshallObject() which identifies method calls, etc. and marshalls them efficiently.

The drawback is that every time a List is used as a parameter, an ArrayList is received when unmarshalling.  Even if the List passed in is a LinkedList or any other List implementation.

column1: TimeoutException (and lock ownership problem) under load test
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
I have run into this problem occasionally when doing JBossCache perf test (in REPL_SYNC mode). But very often in PojoCache perf test. In PojoCache perf test, here are the access pattern. Note that there should not be any write contention. All the data structure should be like http session (e.g., /JSESSION/localhost/hostnamexxx/threadIdxx/). And I have one big putObject (within a tx context) follow by 9 individual field update (no tx with plain put). I have like 50 threads running concurrently. 

Here is a snippet for the problem (I believe in replciated node, 10.68.4.57:32881). Notice this request has errorenous lock ownership of [GlobalTransaction:<10.68.8.57:32855>:22]

column293: 02/May/06 10:59 AM;manik;The problem is that this is a race condition where between receiving a broadcast for a prepare and broadcast for a commit, another (non transactional) call is received and we see a stale gtx in thread local on the remote cache for this non-tx call.

org.jboss.cache.transaction.InvocationContextCleanupTest

build.bat one-test-aop -Dtest=org.jboss.cache.aop.collection.ReplicatedSyncListTest 

or

build.sh one-test-aop -Dtest=org.jboss.cache.aop.collection.ReplicatedSyncListTest
column296:
01/May/06 11:48 PM;clebert.suconic;This is in part related to JBSER-69.

But on the other hand, you should never write class references to AOPProxies because they won't behave the same as java.lang.Proxies.

when writing a java.lang.Proxy, java.io.ObjectOutputSTream would identify the class reference is a proxy and it would generate extra information to load the class with exact same properties.
But with AOPProxy there is no way to guarantee that behavior.

This is a bug, and it should be verified.

column294: 08/Nov/06 5:41 AM;manik;Reopened to add an Enum to nodeModified() event so it identifies whether data has been added, removed or modified.  Data map passed in would only contain data added, removed or modified.
column295: 08/Nov/06 5:42 AM;manik;See JBCACHE-388
column296:
08/Nov/06 10:28 AM;manik;Cool. One other small thing: for completeness the MapModifications struct should probably also have a "public Map unmodifiedEntries" field. Manik Surtani wrote: Ok, sounds cool, will add this to the JIRA task. How about a variation on Ben's idea of providing an enum to specify the type of change? Sample API follows. /** * Called before and after a {@link Node} is modified. Data passed in the * modData param can be used to determine what was modified. *

* When called with pre == true, modData is the * initial state of the {@link Node} before modification. *

* When called with pre == false, the contents of modData * depend on the value of modTtype: *

    *
  • PUT_KEY_VALUE: Map contains the single key/value pair that was added.
    • *
  • REMOVE_KEY_VALUE: Map contains the single key/value pair that was removed.
    • *
  • PUT_MAP: Map contains the new state of the {@link Node} following modification. * This map includes modified key/value pairs as well as any that were not affected.
    • *
*

* Implementations interested in seeing the difference in the node data in the PUT_MAP case * can cache the modData map passed when pre == true, and then * when the pre == false callback is received, pass the cached map and the new * modData to {@link org.jboss.cache.util.Util.diffNodeData(Map pre, Map post)}. * * @param fqn Fqn of the node being modified * @param pre true if the modification is about to be applied, * false if it has already been applied * @param isLocal true if the modification originated locally, * false if it was replicated from another node * @param modType PUT_KEY_VALUE, REMOVE_KEY_VALUE or PUT_MAP * @param modData Unmodifiable {@link Map}; will not be null. See * description above. */ public void nodeModified(Fqn fqn, boolean pre, boolean isLocal, ModificationType modType, Map modData); public class Util { public static MapModifications diffNodeData(Map pre, Map post) { // do the diff here } public static class MapModifications { public Map addedEntries; public Map removedEntries; public Map modifiedEntries; } } Advantage here is JBC goes to little effort to support this, so overhead is low if the listener isn't interested. CacheListener impls that are interested in modifications, but where the app never calls put(Fqn, Map) also have very little overhead. I believe Jerry's DistributedState is such a case. The big overhead of doing the diff is only incurred by CacheListener impls that care, and we provide much of the code to do it for them.

column293:
28/Apr/06 12:12 AM;ben.wang;Note that I have changed the title slightly because I found out this is a problem from TreeCache. Here is how to reproduce using plain JBossCache:

1. Use async mode
2. Use tx
3. The replicated node will produce such exception

I have vierfied this using the perf test org.jboss.cache.Server:

1. 1 thread and 1 loop
2. tx = on
3. has 2 node cluster and turn on log file
4. run the 2 second node as receiver only: benchmark.sh -config bench.txt -receiver
5. check the log file for the second node.
column294:
28/Apr/06 7:17 AM;manik;Thanks for spotting this and providing easy steps to recreate.  Fixed now, I traced it down to an incorrect handling of 1-phase commits on the remote node where the tx interceptor was passing this call up the interceptor chain after applying mods (normal behaviour for prepare calls).  And then if it was a 1-phase commit, it attempted to commit the tx which ended up with the call going up the stack again!  The solution - and correct handling of 1-phase commits - is not to pass the prepare call up the stack until the commit is called (internally by the tx interceptor).

This fix is in CVS now.

column1: Performance of Method.equals
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
Method.equals() method is not as optimised as it was expected. This method is called
quite often in JBossCache, specially in the interceptors. This feature involves taking advantage
of the serialisation optimisations developed by Manik in order to avoid calling Method.equals() 
and instead, comparing the byte numbers associated with each method.
column293:
16/May/06 6:20 PM;galder.zamarreno;Changes:

- JGroups version has been upgraded to 2.2.9.1
- Change comparisons based of Method.equals() to comparisons based on id of the MethodCall;
- unmarshallMethodCall() and marshallMethodCall() methods in EnhancedTreeCacheMarshaller have been modified to write and read shorts instead of bytes for the method id.
- Refactored Method (from TreeCache), method_id(from EnhancedTreeCacheMarshaller) and crud method definitions to a class called MethodDeclarations. This also include lookupMethod(), lookupMethodId() and isCrudMethod() methods.
- Chain of if comparisons based on method id have been converted into switch statements to improve the performance of the code. One call to getId() against several calls and check of if statements.
- Three new method ids have been created for those Method definitions that did not have method ids defined.
- method id definitions are now int instead of Byte. This is also to improve performance.
- A class called MethodCallFactory has been created with a single method called create() which creates an instance of MethodCall and calls setId(). All new MethodCall statements have been substituted with the factory method call.
column294: 16/May/06 6:45 PM;galder.zamarreno;Code changed and committed as per comment.

column1: Optimize PojoCache in local mode

column54: Effort to optimize the PojoCache performance on LOCAL mode. This this first step towards optimizing during distributed case.
column293:
19/Apr/06 4:58 AM;ben.wang;In previous attempt, the numbers were erroroneous becuase the pojo are not aspectized correctly. Here is a re-run. All runs here are REPL mode but with a single node (so there is no replication, in reality).

We have also used List to benchmark (instead of Set) since it seems to perform better now. We are running benchmark-pojocache.sh.

This was run on cluster02 machine.

1. list=1, 1 thread, 75 req/sec, pojo put every time
2. #1, 10 thread, 329 req/sec
3. #1, 50 thread, 590 req/sec
4. #3, treecache, 7824 req/sec (becuase of only one put per req)
5. #3, pojo update every 10th time, 5386 req/sec
column294:
20/Apr/06 2:15 AM;ben.wang;After couple of optimization by 1) remove some redudant codes, 2) consolidating the cache.put into cache.put(fqn, map), here is the new number for PojoCache.

#6, same as #3 with new code base, 731 req/sec
#7. #6 but with list=100, 55 req/sec (this one is slow is expected since it need to actively map the list 100 times).
column295:
24/Apr/06 11:52 AM;ben.wang;The latest optimization number:

8. same as #1, 134 req/sec
9. #3, 960 req/sec
10. #7,  800 req/sec

Latest payload size:

PojoCache:

list=1, 2907 bytes
list=100, 34927 bytes
list=100, 6545 bytes using COMPRESS (level=1)

TreeCache:

list=1, 646 bytes
list=100, 6636 bytes
column296:
01/May/06 3:50 AM;ben.wang;This is pre-1.4Alpha version (05/01/06) profiling data under JProfiler. The snapshot is attached. This is for repeatedly putObject with pojo of list size=100 (from the perf tester). The profiling is for 24 times of putObject and it results in:

cache.get(), 2383x3 times, 38.2% cpu
cache.put() - 2383x2 times, 33.7% cpu

Further profiling of plain cache get/put operations shows the bottleneck mostly in lock and tx interceptor (even with local mode). Note that PojoCache results in 100 times more of get/put becuase of the List size of 100 (so we have to iterate thru the list 100 times). Obviously, becuase of plain cache local mode is still too expensive, it adds up in total.

Here are couple of solutions:

1. Create a pojo level lock, then all get operation can bypass lock interceptor (since we don't need it anymore). What about put operation? We want to bypass the lock operation but not the tx interceptor.

2. This can combine with a different kind of pojo mapping. E.g., we do map it in fine-grained from cache1. Instead, we will send the pojo over to cache2 directly and then do the mapping from there. Furthermore, the operation will be transactional in one shot.
column297: 01/May/06 3:52 AM;ben.wang;This is profiling snapshot under JProfiler for PojoCache with list=100.
column298:
01/May/06 5:52 AM;ben.wang;Pre-1.4Alpha version (05/01) on cluster02 machine.

#20 same as #1 1110 req/sec
#21 same as #7 96 req/sec
column299:
01/May/06 11:34 PM;ben.wang;Post-alpha (05/02) on cluster02, after optimization on using _get() to bypass lock/tx interceptors plus reduce one more put() in regularePutObject

#22 same as #21 176 req/sec
#23 same as #22 but 2 node cluster, 120 req/sec

As it stands now using JProfiler, 40% of time is spent on put() method call (since there are lots of them), 10% on resolving the annotation, and 10% on creating new nodes.
column300: 02/May/06 10:38 PM;ben.wang;I am wrapping this stage of optimization. Overall, we are getting at leat a factor of 4 speedup when the list size is significant.
column301: 04/May/06 12:40 PM;ben.wang;latest one.
column302:
09/May/06 9:18 PM;ben.wang;The latest number from 1.4beta is

#24 same as #22, 302 request/sec.

column1: cache loader file location property isn't parsed correctly under JBoss AS
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
I have been refactoring the ejb3 sfsb replication using JBossCache. One of the feature is using the passivation and specify the cache loader file location.

However, the JBoss defined property "${jboss.server.data.dir} is not parsed correctly in CacheLoaderConfig.setProperties of JBossCache. When reading it in through InputStream, it will strip off the "\" character as escape sequence, although it is "\\" already. I think somehow the character encoding is srrewed up.

Note that this problem does not show up in JBossCache standalone mode though. I have tried to read it in through xml in the unit test. It'd pass.

Attached is the cache file that demonstrates this. To reproduce it, drop this file in under all directory and watch the IOException. Or alternatively, by specify "e:\tmp\testCase" would have the same effect.

This is cricital bug for SFSB now.
column293: 04/Apr/06 6:31 AM;ben.wang;Note that the attached xml uses 1.2.4 style cacheloader. But 1.3 cacheloader also fails as well.
column295:
04/Apr/06 8:20 AM;smarlow;Oops, properties class is hacked to expect 8859-1, code should be:

             ByteArrayInputStream is = new ByteArrayInputStream(properties.trim().getBytes("ISO8859_1"));
column296: 04/Apr/06 11:05 AM;ben.wang;OK, I tested it on my XP and it works now! Problem that I had earlier was that I was using build instead of build jar. As a result, jboss-cache.jar didn't get updated so I didn't see my previous ISO8859_1 working. BTW, it seems both "ISO-8859-1" and "ISO8859_1" are working. What's the deal?
column297:
04/Apr/06 11:18 AM;smarlow;Sun created an alias for ISO8859_1 to be the same as ISO-8859-1 (see http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.3/docs/guide/intl/encoding.doc.html)

The fix is in /cvsroot/jboss/JBossCache/src/org/jboss/cache/config/CacheLoaderConfig.java revision 1.8

Would should I do next to help with this?  I'm not sure how to create a patch or who does that.
column298:
05/Apr/06 3:52 PM;smarlow;I traced this to  org.jboss.util.propertyeditor.PropertiesEditor.getValue calling the java.util.Properties.load method which is processing escape sequences found in the inputstream parameter.

jdk doc for properties.load:

"
public void load(InputStream inStream)
          throws IOException

    Reads a property list (key and element pairs) from the input stream. The stream is assumed to be using the ISO 8859-1 character encoding; that is each byte is one Latin1 character. Characters not in Latin1, and certain special characters, can be represented in keys and elements using escape sequences similar to those used for character and string literals (see §3.3 and §3.10.6 of the Java Language Specification). The differences from the character escape sequences used for characters and strings are:

        * Octal escapes are not recognized.
        * The character sequence \b does not represent a backspace character.
        * The method does not treat a backslash character, \, before a non-valid escape character as an error; the backslash is silently dropped. For example, in a Java string the sequence "\z" would cause a compile time error. In contrast, this method silently drops the backslash. Therefore, this method treats the two character sequence "\b" as equivalent to the single character 'b'.
        * Escapes are not necessary for single and double quotes; however, by the rule above, single and double quote characters preceded by a backslash still yield single and double quote characters, respectively. 

    An IllegalArgumentException is thrown if a malformed Unicode escape appears in the input.

    This method processes input in terms of lines. A natural line of input is terminated either by a set of line terminator characters (\n or \r or \r\n) or by the end of the file. A natural line may be either a blank line, a comment line, or hold some part of a key-element pair. The logical line holding all the data for a key-element pair may be spread out across several adjacent natural lines by escaping the line terminator sequence with a backslash character, \. Note that a comment line cannot be extended in this manner; every natural line that is a comment must have its own comment indicator, as described below. If a logical line is continued over several natural lines, the continuation lines receive further processing, also described below. Lines are read from the input stream until end of file is reached. 
"
column299: 05/Apr/06 4:00 PM;smarlow;We probably need to stop using the java.util.properties call or make sure that values we pass into the properties class are properly escaped when converting from java to byte array.
column300: 07/Apr/06 3:36 AM;ben.wang;It doesn't change anything but just for the reference, if we use 1.3 style CacheLoaderConfig (of which I was testing in the first place), then we are calling setProperties(String properties) instead. But the issue of ${jboss.server.data.dir} is still the same.
column301: 07/Apr/06 3:45 AM;ben.wang;This one uses 1.3 style cache loader config.

column1: During putObject in PojoCache, we should do a collective put for the primitive fields
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54: Currently during putObject call, the field mapping is done via put(fqn, field, value) iteratively. This can lead to inefficiency if there are a lot of fields dur to size bloat during serialization. Solution is to collect those put into put(fqn, map) call.

column1: Create a default marshaller for JBossCache
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54: Currently we use org.jgroups.util.Util.objectToByteBuffer and objectFromByteBuffer. But it is synchronized on ByteArrayOutputStream and can be potentially slow.
column293: 28/Mar/06 11:10 AM;belaban;This could use JBoss Serialization and / or Streamable
column294:
28/Mar/06 11:14 AM;clebert.suconic;JBossSerialization should be decoupled.


ObjectOutputStream out = StreamingFactory.newObjectout(byteOut);


JBossRemoting has an equivalent interface that we call SerializationManager.

If you can have a dependency on JBossRemoting, this should be fine. If you cant, we would need to copy that factory, what would be pretty simple.

column1: putObject() should check for "__jboss::internal__" keys
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54: If such a key is seen, putObject()/removeObject() should throw an IllegalArg exception. This way, we prevent users from accidentally (or maliciously) overwriting PojoCache internal metadata
column294: 02/Apr/06 11:16 PM;ben.wang;We should in theory support generic object. But our eviction and cacheloader all have the limitation of accepting only String type now. PojoCache also has some limitation on this end although we can address this.

column1: OOM during perf test under repl_sync mode
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
I have run into OOM when running the sync perf test in the Atl lab. Here are some details to reproduce it:

1. Machines are dev02, 03, and 04
2. Used the driver JBCACHE-503 to run it.
3. Used sync mode that causes the replication timeout exception. 

It is supposedly not to have any more threads that causing the leak because the threads are stuck in the JGroups queue. However, it is leaking memory over time.

I have attached the config files.
column293: 04/May/06 7:37 PM;manik;Just tried this on the lab cluster with 3 nodes in the cluster, with the latest srcs from HEAD and didn't see any OOMEs.  Have you seen this when testing on the lab cluster?
column294: 22/Jun/06 10:46 AM;ben.wang;I know it is weird but it was kind of intermittent last time that I tested. If you can't reproduce it, let's either put it off or close it then.

column1: Optimise references when streaming data on the wire
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54: E.g., prepare() calls may have multiple get()s and put()s, each referencing the same GlobalTransaction object.  We should not have to serialise this gtx multiple times.

column1: Optimise marshalling of Fqn, GlobalTransaction, etc
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54: Use Streamable for these objects to improve marshalling and transmission performance
column293: 15/Mar/06 2:26 AM;belaban;Make sure you don't use the Streamable interface from JGroups, but let's create our own. Inside JBossCache, or - even better - JBoss Serialization
column294:
07/Apr/06 5:28 AM;manik;"
I'm going to change this so that RpcEngine uses a new class (org.jboss.cache.serialization.Serializer) to serialize the MethodCall and its payload using the same concepts - ids for methods, magic numbers for known types (Fqn, Gtx, IpAddress etc), optimisations for common types (String, Integer).

We could then enhance this Serializer to:
  1.  call JBossSerialization for user types in payloads
  2.  perform reference counting and optimisation here


"
column295:
20/Apr/06 10:08 AM;manik;Ok, this is now in the EnhancedTreeCacheMarshaller.

We still use the JGroups-provided RPcDispatcher since there is little point in re-implementing this.

EnhancedTreeCacheMarshaller maintains a notion of magic numbers for known classes and is able to marshall/unmarshall accordingly.  User-defined objects are serialized using ObjectSerializationFactory.createObjectInput/OutputStream() which creates either a standard java.io.ObjectInput/OutputStream or a org.jboss.serial.io.JBossObjectInput/OutputStream based on a system property.

The default is to use the JBoss Serialization classes.

column1: Create a JBossCache performance test
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
I am creating a test similar to JGroups perf test to measure the overall throughput. It has been checked in under JBossCache/tests/scripts. The main driver is org.jboss.cache.Server under perf directory.

It has the following features:

1. Setup individually on each cluster node and it will wait untill the clustering group is ready before sending the request
2. Request consists of a complex object (Sutdent) with configurable Courses (a list). It is generated randomly from the RandomString class so OutputObjectStream can't do any optimization to skip the payload.
3. Has an option to specify as receiver only mode (i.e., no send request)
4. Can run w/ or w/out transaction
5. Specify number of threads and loops
6. Monitor the time run on each thread
7. Count the exceptions, if there is any
column56: Complete the test and setup.;13/Mar/06 9:51 PM;ben.wang;57600

column1: Need customized serialization to minimize PojoCache payload
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
This discovery comes from the profiling. During a putObject, since it breaks down the pojo into primitive puts, it will generate on the cache level, under _replicate, _prepare method call, a bunch of _put calls. Problem is that these calls have many repetitive information, e.g., gtx, dest address, class metadata, etc. But the default ObjectOutputStream does not know how to optimize it. As a result, it generates a very big payload so we need a special read/write external to handle it ourself.

Currently, we also have plan to convert the methodcall payload into id. So the remaining issue is mostly the ref count for gtx and address, IMO. Maybe there are others though.

We will do this on the TreeCacheMarshaller level, btw, where JGroups will call objectFromByte and objectToByte are called by JGroups.

column294:
28/Mar/06 12:46 AM;ben.wang;To optimize the payload, couple things need to be done:

1. Use method id to replace MethodCall object in TreeCache. Needed are: replicate, prepare, put, remove, GlobalTransaction, Address, Fqn.

2. However, that still leaves things like Fqn that can occupy a lot of spaces. We also have AOPInstance class that needs to optimize it away.

3. We can lump all the call under the same fqn into put(fqn, map) instead. This should saves quite a lot of spaces.

column300:
07/May/06 9:45 PM;ben.wang;Here is the latest comment from the private email conversation. Optimization has been done in EnhancedTreeCacheMarshaller for 1) handle primitive type marshalling, 2) use ref counting for the marshalled object.

OK, I have run my PojoCache test again. Here is what I found using a 2 node cluster. The pojo again is a Student with 100 courses.

1. Pre-5/6 run, 1.4 post-Alpha, 113 req/sec, 22.6KByte. (Note that this has some of Manik's update already. The original object was 25K.)

2. 5/7 snapshot (with the latest), 117 req/sec, 19.5KByte

3. Same as #2 but using Java.io package (instead of JBossSerialization), 123 req/sec, 17.3KByte

So we can see that it does reduce the payload size in my case and some speed up in performance. Unfortunately, I think we are reaching the top here. When I trace it thru the debugger, here is what I found:

1. The AOPInstance is taking about 20 bytes from each Course. Not much I can do about here since turning it into Externalizable is about the same as Serializable (because I only have a int field write).
2. gtx+fqn is taking about 25 bytes here 3. Finally, there are the real fields here that uses up 120 bytes (including String ref count)

So that mulitplied by 100, we are getting this 17Kb number.

column1: Eviciton imporperly thrown when an eviction node not found
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
Issue raised in Forum. Here is what happened.

1. cache.put("/test/1/2", key, val);
// eviction thread kick in. However, /test is evicted before /test/1/2 and since it has children, it only removes the data not the fqn. That is, at the end of this eviction, there is node /test with empty content.

2. cache.put("/test/1/2", key, val) again. However, this wont create "/test" because it is there already (no event is generated). Therefore, no eviction will be placed on "/test" fqn because it is empty.

3. cache.remove("/"). This will attempt to remove "/test" but the event is not on the evition queue.

Obviously we should allow this so the exception thrown is overly restricted. Solution is to comment out the exception and return right away by just loggin the warning as "WARN", at best.

Another solution is to evict in the LIFO fashion. But this is not fool proof either.
column293: 08/Mar/06 3:29 AM;ben.wang;I am checking fix for both 1.3 and post-1.2.4SP2 branch. There is not patch scheduled yet since this is more of a corner case.

column1: Switch to JBoss Serialization for replication/storage
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54: Use JBoss serialization rather than java.io Serialization, wherever we use readObject(), should result in a speedup
column293:
05/Apr/06 7:42 AM;manik;I presume this is regarding cache content rather than any of our nternal objects, for which we should have our own marshaller (e.g., Fqn, Gtx, MethodId, etc).

I also presume this will have a dependency on JBoss Serialization solving it's current issue with generating a large number of bytes for each object it serializes.  Is there an open JIRA task for this in JBoss Serialization?
column294: 19/Apr/06 1:51 PM;manik;JBCACHE-517
column295: 21/Apr/06 6:02 PM;clebert.suconic;I'm working on JBSER-60 now.
column296:
21/Apr/06 10:31 PM;clebert.suconic;The problem basicaly is related to Class references.
Java Serializatio treats Classes as regular references, hence once a class is written the class is only written once.

With JBoss Serialization I'm describing the classname and Classfields every time a object is serialized. 
After fixed that, the size of JBossSerialization streaming is going to be <= JavaSerialization. This should be fixed in two or three days now.
column297:
24/Apr/06 9:23 PM;clebert.suconic;I have finished JBSER-60.

Performance looks much better now, not just sizing of the stream.

I will be releasing in a couple days. There isn't much to be done before releasing. Buf if you can use CVS for tests you could use it  already.

If you want to, I can update snapshot, and change jboss-head to snapshot.

column1: Multiple attempts to remove an AOP object on putObject()
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
TreeCacheAopDelegate._putObject() calls cache_.removeObject(fqn) to first remove any current object at the FQN. CollectionClassHandler.collectionObjectPut() also calls cache_.removeObject(fqn).

This isn't a big issue, as the second remove will fail relatively quickly, but it's wasted effort.

column1: HEAD Fails org.jboss.cache.ConcurrentEvictAndRemoveTest Due To ConcurrentModificationExceptions
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column54:
When running org.jboss.cache.ConcurrentEvictAndRemoveTest, the changing of the lock list for a given thread coupled with the printing of the lock table when TRACE is enabled for the UnlockInterceptor causes a ConcurrentModificationException to be thrown.

If this kind of TRACE logging is required in UnlockInterceptor, the list of locks for a given thread in the lock table needs to be a synchronized List (just like the lock table is a synchronized Map).

I'll attach a diff for PessimisticLockInterceptor.java that changes the lock list so that it is synchronized.
column56: Corrected failure of org.jboss.cache.ConcurrentEvictAndRemoveTest due to ConcurrentModificationExceptions by changing the lock list for a given thread to be a synchronized List.;14/Feb/06 1:12 AM;jiwils;3600

column293:
26/Oct/05 2:40 PM;neotyk;Patch fixing the bug.
public void prepare(Object tx, List modifications, boolean one_phase) throws Exception
at line 530 you took Connection from managedConnectionPool, than used it only for
debuging purposes at line 534.
And as far as I understund 2PC, in prepare state you have just stopped using connection,
and container is executing Prepare phase, to Commit or Rollback Tx, so this code was probably some
copy'n'paste technology error.
column294: 27/Jan/06 9:33 AM;manik;What's the status of this task?
column295:
31/Jan/06 1:48 PM;hmesha;In solving this issue, I found out that the ManagedConnectionFactory is only used within a transaction scope. Also, a ManagedConnectionFactory   almost always has a connection pool associated with and distributed transaction ready.  Therfore, we don't really need to call prepare() on it but we need a prepare() method to conform to the ConnectionFactory interface contract. So the change I made is to wrap the connection factory prepare call in an if condition to check the type of the connection factory that we're dealing with and that decide weather we'll prepare or not. Although the patch has the right idea but the solution would have broke the NonManagedConnectionFactory prepare().

Aslo, I added test cases (JDBCCacheLoaderMySQLDSTestCase, JDBCCacheLoaderDerbyDSTestCase) to the testsuite to be run manaually to test DataSource configuration. Those test cases need to be run manually because they fail on TestTransactionRollback(). The reason being that data source objects don't have transaction support without being run inside an App server. In order to run the test, change the class name from *TestCase to *Test and save.

column1: Cached map uses toString() of key to create FQN
column11: A replicated, transactional, persistent and structured cache service.
column293: 01/Sep/05 8:34 PM;ben.wang;tim, if you can't complete this by next week, I will need to move it into 1.2.4.
column294: 05/Sep/05 10:58 PM;ben.wang;btw, we can't currently uses hascode() now since it can cause a recursive loop with a non-primitive pojo as key. Please see JBCACHE-278.
column295:
05/Sep/05 11:33 PM;twundke;There's no difference between hashcode() and toString(). Both can result in the infinite loop problem. I think it's actually more likely that toString() will be overridden.

Note also that I think that JBCACHE-278 only applies when the key object is contained within the value object. I could be entirely wrong here, but that's the only time that I've seen this occur.
column296:
07/Sep/05 2:32 AM;ben.wang;Tim, your check in resulted couple failure in functionalAopTests. Please remember to run the tests before and after your fix otherwise it is creating extra burden for me. Please take a look otherwise I will rollback your change.

toString will only result in recursive loop if it is used inside the interceptor (of which it is not now).
column297:
07/Sep/05 4:21 AM;twundke;Ben, you're correct. I did run the tests, but got side-tracked and did the check in anyway. Sorry 'bout that. I've rolled back the change myself as it's not a general solution. Unfortunately time is against me with "real" work, so I'll move it to a later release. It's obviously not a big problem with most people at the moment anyway.

As for toString(), it gets called on the key when the Fqn is created in AopUtil.constructFqn().

column1: Change maven classpath ordering for dependencies
column11: JBoss project builds and the JBoss Maven repository.
column54:
Currently maven puts transitive dependencies first in the compile and test classpaths.  It would be better to have direct dependencies listed first.
See this maven issue: http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MNG-3197
column56: Created a maven patch for this.  Will close this issue when the maven issue is resolved.;14/Sep/07 5:02 PM;pgier;43200
column293: 08/Jan/08 12:02 PM;pgier;A patch was added to the maven issue.  This problem mainly occurs when a dependency has been renamed, and the older version (before the rename) comes before the direct dependency on the newer version with the new name.  The workaround for this until it gets fixed in maven core is to exclude any transitive dependency that is causing a problem.

column56:
Attempted to build jbossretro as maven plugin, but there were problems with the JavaMojoDescriptorExtractor.java.  When the descriptor extractor encountered org.jboss.lang.annotation.Inherited.java the build crashed because maven plugin believes this is not a valid Java class.
I fixed this in the maven source code and created a maven bug report with the fix here:
http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MNG-2799

I decided that it would be better to build jbossretro as it, and then create a separate maven plugin that depends on the jbossretro jar.

Created pom.xml for jbossretro and javassist (dependency of jbossretro).

Started a new project called jboss-retro-maven-plugin.

        at org.jboss.ant.types.Compatible.compareTo(Compatible.java:76)

[/code]

I was able to reproduce this NPE in the org.jboss.test.VersionTest with the new testWordAgainstNumberBug test.  I also created more extensive tests to make sure I introduced no regressions.

column1: ant searched along $PATH, not using the jboss's version
column11: JBoss project builds and the JBoss Maven repository.
column54:
Building jboss-4.0 with a new checkout failed for me.

Solaris comes with an ant package installed on /usr/sfw.
Running jboss's build.sh this script searches ant and preferres the version inside the jboss source tree.

In tools/etc/jbossbuild/tasks.xml ant is called without a fixed path. So it is searched along $PATH.
So /usr/sfw/bin/ant was found and used here and throwed errors about SAXParser..Impl.

Taking /usr/sfw/bin out of $PATH and putting in $JBOSS_HOME/jboss-4.0/tools/bin solved this problem.
But in tools/etc/jbossbuild/tasks.xml $ANT_HOME/bin/ant should be used as ${execant-executable}.
column56: Had to learn how the execant macro was functioning and then figure out a work around.   Wrote a new ant task to execute a target without reparsing the ant file.;28/Jul/05 10:28 AM;ruel.loehr;14400
column293:
27/Jul/05 9:36 PM;ruel.loehr;Verified.  

This happens because we are using a macro which launches a new ant using the $ANT_HOME instead of the ant in the jboss path (which build.sh instructs us to use)

If I try to substitute an <antcall> or <ant> in place of the macro, we get an error saying that we are duplicating the build object which is defined in the thirdparty-build.xml file.    Antcall and ant each re-read the file they are being called on and  because ant requires distinct id's for the objects and build is a static object .... we have a problem.

The goal is here is to be able to call the synchronize.components  using the the jboss defined version of ant.  One solution to this would be to write our own task, "execute-target".   This would accept a string, "target".   In this task we could access the project object and with it call the executeTarget method.   This task would be used instead of the macro call.
column294: 28/Jul/05 10:30 AM;ruel.loehr;Wrote an task to replace the macro call.  This task simply executes an ant target BUT does it without reparsing the file as <ant> or <antcall> would do.   Tested this by removing my ant_home and verifying that ant could not be found.   Then executed ./build.sh and everything is working fine.

column1: Resolve final libraries.ent location
column11: JBoss project builds and the JBoss Maven repository.
column54: Determine where the generated libraries.ent should reside, modify file generator to place it in the the correct location
column293: 13/Jul/05 10:04 AM;ruel.loehr;Location of generated libraries.ent will be thirdparty/buildfiles/libraries.ent.    This is configurable in the target which generates the file.
column294:
14/Jul/05 1:53 PM;ruel.loehr;When integrating this with the existing build I found some problems.  Namely, when the build is started, this file is not created yet, so ANT will fail.         This is due to the defintion of the import in the build/build.xml file. (<!ENTITY buildmagic SYSTEM "../tools/thirdparty/libraries.ent">).

 Scott's suggestion in the build forum is as follows:

The libraries are only used by the main build when creating the dist. They have no purpose for building thirdparty or compiling the modules. Couldn't we simply break out the install target into a seperate build-dist.xml file that contains the install and related targets?

Unless you do this, the initial build will be using the obsolete ../tools/buildmagic/etc/libraries.ent version and would fail anyway when the incorrect libraries were used.

This is correct.

The install target is actually many targets.  The existing buildmagic system uses a process such that if  a target exists such as :  <target name="_module-j2ee-most">, then it will be executed during the most build.   For most modules, targets such as these are defined.   The caveat is that they must be present in the main build file, otherwise the buildmagic system will just skip over them.   These targets are where the deployment operations take place (copying thirdparty files to certain places).

I have implemented this locally and made it work.   Changes are as follows:

Build/build.xml
1)  removal of reference to libraries.ent
2)  properties for output structure moved to external file (they will need to be used by other xml files)
3)  all module targets now call targets defined in file build-dist.xml (this removes the dependency on the libraries.ent file)

Module build files
1)  change the location of libraries.ent file

build-distr.xml
1)  this file contains all of the targets which copy thirdparty files to output directories
2)  it is also where the libraries.ent location is defined

install-structure.properties
1) contains properties which define the output structure, used by build.xml and build-distr.xml
column295: 14/Jul/05 3:07 PM;ruel.loehr;Awaiting deployment.

column1: Exception when trying to delete a comment created by a different user
column11: The JBoss Blog portlet project.
column54:
The following exception is thrown:

Caused by: java.util.ConcurrentModificationException
        at java.util.HashMap$HashIterator.nextEntry(HashMap.java:841)
        at java.util.HashMap$ValueIterator.next(HashMap.java:871)
        at org.hibernate.pretty.Printer.toString(Printer.java:90)
        at org.hibernate.event.def.AbstractFlushingEventListener.flushEverythingToExecutions(AbstractFlushingEventListener.java:97)
        at org.hibernate.event.def.DefaultFlushEventListener.onFlush(DefaultFlushEventListener.java:26)
        at org.hibernate.impl.SessionImpl.flush(SessionImpl.java:1000)
        at org.jboss.blog.service.store.hibernate.HibernateBlogStoreService.deleteComment(Unknown Source)
column293:
11/Apr/07 4:38 AM;velthuiz;This error has also been found in version 3.2.3.

A simple workaround is to turn of debug logging for this class in the log4J.properties file (or in log4j.xml when using jboss)

   <category name="org.hibernate.event.def.AbstractFlushingEventListener">
     <priority value="WARN" />
     <appender-ref ref="CONSOLE"/>
   </category>

This way, the iterator is not created and thus the error does not occur.

column1: Suport for exposing JMX bean as ManagedObject
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54: To facilitate creation of ManagedObjects from existing JMX beans, we need better support for generating the ManagedObject from MBeanInfo
column57:
A new ManagedMBeanDeploymentFactory interface and callbacks have been added for use in the ManagementViewImpl. One can map an mbean to a ManagedDeployment/ManagedComponent using the current basic implementation of ManagedMBeanDeploymentFactory, An example can be found in the profileservice-jboss-beans.xml:

    <bean name="WarManagerManagedDeploymentFactory"
        class="org.jboss.profileservice.management.ProxyManagedDeploymentFactory">
        <property name="factoryName">WarManager</property>
        <property name="compType">MBean</property>
        <property name="compSubtype">WebApplicationManager</property>
        <property name="pattern">jboss.web:host=localhost,type=Manager,*</property>
        <property name="patternKey">path</property>

    </bean>
    <bean name="WebModuleManagedDeploymentFactory"
        class="org.jboss.profileservice.management.ProxyManagedDeploymentFactory">
        <property name="factoryName">WebModule</property>
        <property name="compType">MBean</property>
        <property name="compSubtype">WebApplication</property>
        <property name="pattern">jboss.web:J2EEApplication=none,J2EEServer=none,j2eeType=WebModule,*</property>
        <property name="patternKey">name</property>
        <property name="componetInfo">
            <map keyClass="java.lang.String" valueClass="java.lang.String">
                <!-- Process the servlets components -->
                <entry>
                    <key>servlets</key>
                    <value>MBean:Servlet</value>
                </entry>
            </map>
        </property>
    </bean>

further discussion can be found on the forum thread.
;04/May/09 5:53 PM;starksm64;28800

column300: 30/Apr/09 12:45 PM;starksm64;TODO: redefine an approach that introduces the override/mapping from a JMX mbean to a ManagedComponent either at the ManagementView bean layer, or as mcbeans in the profileservice-jboss-beans.xml deployment rather than a more general mc beanfactory approach.
column301:
12/May/09 8:57 PM;starksm64;The org.jboss.profileservice.management.ProxyManagedDeploymentFactory bean now has sufficient capability to expose a collections of mbean types as a ManagedDeployment with ManagedComponents. An example of specifying ManagedDeployments for wars is the following bean deployment fragment found in the profileservice-jboss-beans.xml:

    <bean name="SimpleMBeanDeploymentNameBuilder"
        class="org.jboss.profileservice.management.mbean.SimpleMBeanDeploymentNameBuilder">
        <property name="keyName">name</property>
    </bean>
    <bean name="WarManagerMBeanDeploymentNameBuilder"
        class="org.jboss.profileservice.management.mbean.ComplexMBeanDeploymentNameBuilder">
        <property name="prefix">//</property>
        <property name="separator"></property>
        <property name="keyNames">
            <list elementClass="java.lang.String">
                <value>host</value>
                <value>path</value>
            </list>
        </property>
    </bean>
    <bean name="WarManagedDeploymentFactory"
        class="org.jboss.profileservice.management.ProxyManagedDeploymentFactory">
        <property name="factoryName">War</property>

        <property name="defaultViewUse">STATISTIC</property>
        <property name="rootMOPatterns">
            <set elementClass="org.jboss.profileservice.management.ProxyDeploymentInfo">
                <!-- Manager -->
                <bean class="org.jboss.profileservice.management.ProxyDeploymentInfo">
                    <property name="compType">MBean</property>
                    <property name="compSubtype">WebApplicationManager</property>
                    <property name="pattern">jboss.web:host=localhost,type=Manager,*</property>
                    <property name="nameBuilder">
                        <inject bean="WarManagerMBeanDeploymentNameBuilder"/>
                    </property>
                </bean>
                <!-- WebModule -->
                <bean class="org.jboss.profileservice.management.ProxyDeploymentInfo">
                    <property name="compType">MBean</property>
                    <property name="compSubtype">WebApplication</property>
                    <property name="pattern">jboss.web:J2EEApplication=none,J2EEServer=none,j2eeType=WebModule,*</property>
                    <property name="nameBuilder">
                        <inject bean="SimpleMBeanDeploymentNameBuilder"/>
                    </property>
                    <property name="componentInfo">
                        <map keyClass="java.lang.String" valueClass="java.lang.String">
                            <!-- Process the servlets components -->
                            <entry>
                                <key>servlets</key>
                                <value>MBean:Servlet</value>
                            </entry>
                        </map>
                    </property>
                </bean>
            </set>
        </property>
    </bean>

column1: Make HttpNamingContextFactory support jndi SECURITY_PRINCIPAL style logins like /security/src/main/org/jboss/security/jndi/LoginInitialContextFactor
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54: Note that I'm posting this against "SystemService" because for some reason HttpNamingContextFactory is in "server".
column293:
18/Jan/09 12:03 AM;acoliver;1. first a patch that does this (against a checkout of the 4.2 branch at least)
2. a compiled version that you can use by doing jar -xf patch.jar into a directory and then from that directory jar -uf $JBOSS_HOME/client/jbossall-client.jar org/jboss/naming/*.class  (note this assumes you use jboss naming in your client, if you use all the little jars then you will have to figure out which one has HttpNamingContextFactory.class in it)
3. I'll commit this in a sec for later release in 4.2.4 and possibly 5.0.x if I manage to get it to build.

This is a pretty minor little feature that mainly people got used to using in WebLogic but it is a pretty good idea anyhow.

Note the patch differs slightly from the way that LoginInitialContextFactory works.  LoginContextFactory fails if there is no auth.conf (which there is not by default) which is a major pain in Java Web Start style apps.  This trys for the default behavior but if that fails it does the smart thing and uses the default username/password style login module configuration (the DummyConfiguration) without regards to a conf file.  This is much nicer IMO.  I'd fix LoginInitialContextFactory but then I'd have to refactor where these are to avoid duplicating the same code in both places.  I'm unencumbered with a desire to do that at the moment.  If someone else wants to maybe create all of these in one module (  instead of some in security and some in server etc) and maybe give some sanity to the names (subclass them with classes with the old names for compatibility) then I'll go factor this out into common code and add balance to the force.  On the whole LoginInitialContextFactory is kind of boneheaded.  If someone set SECURITY_PRINCIPAL then they probably want this behavior, if they didn't then they don't no need for special versions of things.

column1: HttpSession replication soak testing
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
Long running tests of HttpSession replication under heavy load.

Should include:

1) Letting a significant percentage of sessions passivate and later activate.
2) Letting a significant percentage of sessions expire due to time out.
3) Invalidating remaining sessions after a while (i.e. don't use any sessions for the life of test; all get used and replaced after a while).
4) Perhaps, a low (say 1/1000) probability of failover.

I have some test driver code somewhere that does a lot of this.

column1: MySQLValidConnectionChecker has driver name com.mysql.jdbc.Driver hard coded
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54: The JCA MySQLValidConnectionChecker class has the driver name com.mysql.jdbc.Driver hard coded which prevents it from using any other driver class provided by the standard MySQL library. A good example of this is the replicated driver, which uses class com.mysql.jdbc.ReplicationDriver.
column56: Created the class and tested it.;04/Dec/07 11:12 AM;lucboudreau;3600
column288: Use SQL validation instead of the ping method. OR BETTER YET create a subclass of the faulty validator.
column293: 03/Dec/07 11:01 AM;dimitris;Don't set the priority. Also the affect field must refer to released versions, not future ones.
column294:
03/Dec/07 11:09 AM;adrian.brock;I don't see how this is a bug. There are many checkers for many different drivers/databases.
This one was contributed by somebody that used a specific MySQL driver.

In fact, they got MySQL to implement the feature so they could write the checker in the first place.

Write your own checker for the other driver and contribute it back.

If you want to contribute one that uses java.sql.Connection.isValid() (Java6 only)
that would be nice as well.

Leaving this open as a feature request for somebody that does want to contribute.
column295: 04/Dec/07 11:10 AM;lucboudreau;Here's an implementation for MySQL ReplicationDriver which also supports Java 6 isValid() method if available. If you have any comment, they are most welcome.
column296:
04/Dec/07 11:36 AM;adrian.brock;First, can you add a header that says you license it under the LGPL. Thanks. ;-)
You can just use the standard one which says it is copyrighted according to the @authors tag.

I see you copied the same bug from the original checker.
The class says it is serializable but java.lang.reflect.Method is not serializable
so serialization is broken. ;-)

Otherwise it looks ok.
column297:
04/Dec/07 11:48 AM;lucboudreau;Attached a new version of the class. Now it's fully serializable and released under LGPL.

Cheers !

04/Dec/07 11:59 AM;adrian.brock;It looks the same, did you attach the correct one? :-)
I've deleted both the attachments can you try again.

column301: 04/Dec/07 12:42 PM;lucboudreau;Added Copyright
column302:
04/Dec/07 1:10 PM;adrian.brock;Much better thanks. I've added you to our copyright.txt :-)

I changed the name to MySQLReplicationValidConnectionChecker since that makes more sense.

I also raised a subtask to fix the other checkers that are caching Methods.
When I fix those, I'll also optimize yours so it does cache the Method but as a transient field
and re-initializes the reference in a readObject() method.
Getting the method on every invocation can be slow.

column1: Detecting OutOfMemoryErrors in Servers in the Test Suite
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
We need a custom test runner which checks for OOME's in any running servers between each test.  Optionally, only check for this after a failed test.

See the discussion for details.
column56:

Then you can run ./testsuite/build.sh jboss-memcheck-tests.

column1: failing org.jboss.test.security.test.SRPUnitTestCase - unlimited crypto support needed
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
This is a recurring testsuite failure, whevever we update JDKs, in this case 
Java Version 1.5.0_10 
Java Vendor Sun Microsystems Inc. 

The JDKs must be configured for unlimited crypto support as see in the linked case.

To avoid this problem in the future, configuring crypto support should be part of the process of installing a new JDK.

Download Java(TM) Cryptography Extension (JCE) Unlimited Strength Jurisdiction Policy Files 5.0 from
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/download.jsp
The local_policy.jar and US_export_policy.jar goes under jdk1.x\jre\lib\security\

Please rename the older files at this location before you can copy these unlimited strength files, so they can be used if needed later.

column1: Add a notion of available interfaces to org.jboss.test.util.server.*
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
An issue with automating testing involving binding to specific addresses is that there is no predefined set of properties a testsuite descriptor can reference. The qa env has MYTESTIP_1 type of env vars set, and java 1.4.2+ has java.net.NetworkInterface, that could be used as the basis for defining jboss.server.iface.0..N system properties that configurations could rely on for setting one or more bind interfaces.

We need to add this functionality to the server startup tasks.
column294:
16/Apr/07 4:33 AM;mvecera;New server:addresses task. Works as in comments.
Ant task definition:
<taskdef name="addresses" classname="org.jboss.ant.taskdefs.server.AddressesServerTask"
  uri="http://jboss.org/ns/test/ant/server" loaderref="server.loader">
  <classpath refid="server.taskdef.classpath"/>
</taskdef>
Example of use:
<server:addresses env="MYTESTIP_" prop="jboss.server.iface." ifaces="2"/>

column1: org.jboss.test.jmx.test.JMXConnectorUnitTestCase ends with errors
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
org.jboss.test.jmx.test.JMXConnectorUnitTestCase ends with 9 errors, because of an unavailable service. It tries to connect with:
JMXServiceURL url = new JMXServiceURL("service:jmx:rmi://localhost/jndi/rmi://localhost:1090/jmxconnector");
This service is unavailable, because the "all" instance doesn't deploy jmx-remoting.sar (the "default" instance does).

To fix this, i changed the line 134 in build/build-distr.xml:
         dest="${install.default}/deploy/jmx-remoting.sar"/>
to:
         dest="${install.all}/deploy/jmx-remoting.sar"/>

column1: Role Mapping Login Module that maps application role to declarative role
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
Customers sometime need a feature to map an application role (for example, role from ldap) to a declarative role in web.xml etc. 

Description:
Assume a web.xml defines a security role called as "admin".  Now the user uses ldap login module and authenticates the user called as "X".  But ldap has been configured to assign an role of "ldaprole" to "X".  It should be possible for the user to specify a mapping from "ldaprole" to "admin" such that the authentication passes and access is granted.

A simple RoleMappingLoginModule would suffice that can be configured to replace specific roles in the authenticated subject with roles in the login module options etc.
column293: 20/Jun/06 10:08 AM;starksm64;We should also allow mapping of multiple security domain roles onto multiple application roles so a many to many relationship between the backend security domain to the application exists.
column294:
23/Jun/06 12:09 PM;anil.saldhana;Wiki page is :    http://wiki.jboss.org/wiki/Wiki.jsp?page=RoleMappingLoginModule

Unit Test Case is under
testsuite/src/main/org/jboss/test/security/test/RoleMappingLoginModuleUnitTestCase

column1: Access Control on JMX Operations in the JMX Console
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
Certain users would like to apply fine-grained access control to the JMX Operations in the JMX Console.  Currently we have support for applying authentication/access control at the URI level as defined by the servlet specification.

A servlet filter that allows configurable roles for the various jmx coarse grained operations (updateAttributes, invokeOp).  If the user requires deeper access control, then he should be able to plug in an authorization delegate (which will have priority in making the access control decisions).

12/Jun/06 3:11 PM;anil.saldhana;Applied to Branch_4_0 and HEAD.

column1: ExtendedFormAuthenticator should override authenticate to populate session
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
We need to deprecate FormAuthValve completely. Currently the ExtendedFormAuthenticator does not give an opportunity to populate the session with the username/password if the first attempt at login is successful.

So need to override the "authenticate" method of the FormAuthenticator.

While investigating this issue, I suggest it should be checked whether ExtendedFormAuthenticator can extend the FormAuthenticator that is coming off of the tomcat jars and not the FA that exists in the same package as the EFA.
column56: See comment above for work performed.  In addition, did change to extend Tomcat's FormAuthenticator, as well pushed these changes out to Branch_4_0, and HEAD.;07/Jun/06 3:07 PM;j2ee_junkie;28800
column293: 02/Jun/06 11:26 AM;anil.saldhana;This issue needs to be assigned to Chris Griffith (j2ee_junkie).
column294: 02/Jun/06 12:55 PM;dimitris;I don't see Chris' name appear in the commiter list?
column295: 06/Jun/06 1:08 PM;j2ee_junkie;I extended the authenticate method to handle the case when user successfully authenticated and being redirected back to original url.  I made use of Tomcat's Session notes to ensure populateSession does not happen more than once per request cycle.  I wanted and to extend Tomcat's FormAuthenticator, but there is a bug in matchRequest() as described in http://jira.jboss.com/jira/browse/JBAS-3268.  I updated our FormAuthenticator to fix this bug as well.  Finally, changed signiture of forwardToXPage() methods to reflect that in Tomcat's codebase.

column1: Workaround to avoid OutOfMemoryErrors during jboss boot, under Sun 64-bit linux jdk
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
This is just a work-around for avoiding OutOfMemoryErrors during jboss boot, when running under Sun 64-bit linux jdk. It doesn't guarantee the OOME will not happen, but this is better than nothing, until Sun fixes the broken jdk.

The fix has been tested in HEAD for 3 months without any problems reported so we apply it to the 4.0.x branch, too.

For more info, read the linked forum post.

column1: JBossCacheManager to handle tx exception gracefully
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column54:
1. Currenly under endTransaction, we don't handle RollbackException directly. We need to do that such that the underlying tm can throw a RollbackException that causes the cache store to rollback. We don't need to anything about it if this were the case

2. processExpires uses batch transaction to process. But this should not be necessary since session expiration is a local mode anyway so it won't buy any speed up.

column1: synchronization contention on transaction commits due to TransactionFactory.dropTimeout and newTimeout
column11: This project represents the JBoss Application Server versions 6 and earlier.
column293:
06/Apr/06 9:56 AM;adrian.brock;One thread does not a contention make.
Attach the full thread dump that shows who is holding the lock
and how many are waiting.

More importantly, write a stress test in the testsuite
org.jboss.test.util.test.TimeoutFactoryStressTestCase
that shows the problem.

We should certainly remove the stupid object pooling done by "freeList".

The whole class needs separating into the TimeoutFactory implementation
and the PriorityQueue implementation. It is incomprehensible as it stands. :-)
column294:
06/Apr/06 9:59 AM;adrian.brock;Use this forums thread:
http://www.jboss.com/index.html?module=bb&op=viewtopic&p=3935470#3935470
column295:
13/Apr/06 9:54 AM;adrian.brock;The implementation of the underlying queue has been made pluggable
via a new Interface:

org.jboss.util.timeout.TimeoutPriorityQueue

which can be changed using a system property to define the implementation class,
e.g. when you start JBoss

-Dorg.jboss.util.timeout.TimeoutPriorityQueue=whatever

There is a default implementation that does what was previously done before

org.jboss.util.timeout.TimeoutPriorityQueueImpl

with a couple of simple optimizations.
* Moved the submission to the thread pool outside the synchronized block
* Removed the object pooling

There is also an experimental version that divides the queue into 40 subqueues
based on a internal hashcode.
org.jboss.util.timeout.HashedTimeoutPriorityQueueImpl

So the issue now revolves around finding the most performant PriorityQueue
implementation. This can be done asynchronously with the JBoss release schedule
so I am closing this issue.

New issues can be raised when a more performant implementation is proposed
as the default.
